reviewText:
The story of "A Christmas Carol" and its themes haven't been fresh in people's minds for well over 100 years, which is why the new film adaptation by Robert Zemeckis is so surprising. This is, from my perspective, the definitive version - a sumptuous visual feast that in no way compromises the drama, excitement, and hope of the Charles Dickens classic. Its greatest achievement is not reducing itself to the level of jolly Christmas clichs. The streets and buildings of nineteenth-century London are brightly coated with snow, yet they betray the cold reality of poverty and despair. And Ebenezer Scrooge, having been played by many, many actors over the years, finally looks like the ancient, decrepit, bitter man I always imagined him to be; his face doesn't show the slightest trace of warmth, humor, or charm.

The film's success can be attributed to Zemeckis' love affair with special effects, which in this case involves the same motion capture technology he employed in "The Polar Express" and "Beowulf." This allows for the creation of characters caught in that delightful gray zone between real and unreal. Some are more exaggerated than others; Scrooge - a little too tall, a little too thin, a little too hunched over - is a menacing physical representation of his own anger and resentment. The Ghost of Christmas Past, an elfin wraith with a breathy voice and a head made of fire, is as slight, slender, and soft-spoken as a candle. The Ghost of Christmas Present is a loud and jovial Father Christmas figure, whose laugh is just as big as his body, perhaps bigger. The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come is a silent yet frightening skeletal phantom made out of shadows.

Scrooge and the Ghosts are all played by Jim Carrey, which hardly comes as a shock since he has an affinity for variety of character and over the top performances. Other actors include Gary Oldman as Bob Crachit, Tiny Tim, and Jacob Marley, whose postmortem appearance in Scrooge's bedchamber is intensely creepy, just as it should be. Robin Wright Penn plays both Scrooge's younger sister, Fen, and his neglected fiance, Belle. Bob Hoskins plays old Fezziwig, a man so thoroughly in the Christmas spirit that he and his wife defy gravity as they dance. Colin Firth plays Scrooge's hopelessly optimistic nephew Fred, quite possibly the only person who thinks his uncle is worth addressing in a friendly manner.

As Scrooge is taken on his journey of redemption, both he and the audience are treated to fantastic aerial tours of London, with shots that swoop and soar over rooftops, through windows, and around street corners. 3-D technology, normally so unimpressive, is here perfectly utilized, allowing for one of the most immersive environments of any recent animated film. One of the most stunning sequences involves a spectral carriage chasing a shrunken Scrooge up and down dark, snowy cobblestone streets; it's not only an astounding visual achievement, it's also an exhilarating thrill ride. Harkening back to the roller coaster train sequences created for "The Polar Express," Zemeckis proves that you should stick with what works best.

There are also some equally effective quiet moments, such as the opening shot, which pays homage to classic Disney animated films with the opening of a book. Other moments are surprisingly powerful, as when a grieving Bob Cratchit, his eyes red with tears, seems to be staring directly at Scrooge even though he can't really see him (Cratchit, in that moment, is nothing more than a vision of the future). I also appreciated the shot of doomed ghosts floating just outside Scrooge's window; some of them act humorously, banging their heads against their chain boxes, and yet we can't help but feel sorry for them.

The entire film embodies a darker, shivery tone - not to the point of becoming a computer-animated horror film, but certainly beyond the colorful whimsy of the average Christmas special. This, I believe, truly captures the tone of Dickens' original story, which doesn't spare the reader the hardships of destitution, disease, and loss. Consider Bob Cratchit's family; they do make merry of themselves on Christmas Day, but they also live a meager existence, and there's always the sense that, should nothing about their situation change, they could end up with even less.

Robert Zemeckis created a perennial holiday classic with "The Polar Express," and I think he may have done it again with "A Christmas Carol." Yes, we have seen this movie before, and yes, its message is far from original. But there's no denying the fact that it's sending a good message, where love, compassion, and the possibility of hope reign supreme. There's also no denying that, with visuals this striking, it practically begs to be seen, especially in 3-D. This is one of the year's best looking animated films, so richly detailed, so sharply defined, so gloriously shot. It creates a mood, effectively evoking feelings of warmth and tenderness without becoming sappy or mindlessly cheerful. That above all made seeing this film an absolutely beautiful experience, one that I recommend to everybody.

"A Christmas Carol" is excellent! This is how the story goes: Ebenezer Scrooge begins the Christmas holiday with his usual miserly contempt, barking at his faithful clerk and his cheery nephew. But when the ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Yet to Come take him on an eye-opening journey revealing truths Old Scrooge is reluctant to face, he must open his heart to undo years of ill will before it's too late.

The cast led by Jim Carrey (as Scrooge / Ghost of Christmas Past / Scrooge as a Young Boy / Scrooge as a Teenage Boy / Scrooge as a Young Man / Scrooge as a Middle-Aged Man / Ghost of Christmas Present / Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come) is excellent! The screenplay (based on Charles Dickens' novel) & directing by Robert Zemeckis (also produced) (who also directed "The Polar Express" (2004, also produced and wrote the screenplay), the "Back To The Future" (1985, also wrote the story and screenplay, 1989, also wrote the story & 1990, also wrote the story), "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" (1988), "Forrest Gump" (1994), "Contact" (1997, also produced), "Cast Away" (2000, also produced), "What Lies Beneath" (2000, also produced), & "Beowulf" (2007, also produced) is excellent!

The music by Alan Silvestri (who also did the music to Zemeckis' films since "Romancing The Stone" (1984), he also did the music to "G.I. Joe: The Rise Of Cobra" (2009) & "Night At The Museum: Battle Of The Smithsonian" (2009) is excellent! The cinematography by Robert Presley (who also did the cinematography to "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent! The film editing by Jeremiah O'Driscoll (who also did the film editing to "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent! The casting by Scot Boland, Victoria Burrows (both of did the casting to "The Polar Express" & the upcoming "The Lovely Bones" (2009) & Nina Gold (who also did the casting to "Bewoulf") is excellent! The production design by Doug Chiang (who also did the production design to "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent! The art direction by Marc Gabbana (who was a concept artist on "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") & Mike Stassi (who was an assistant art director on the upcoming "Avatar", "The Polar Express" & "Bewoulf"), he also did the art direction to the upcoming "Alice In Wonderland" (2010) is excellent! The set decoration by Karen O'Hara (who also did the set decoration to the upcoming "Alice In Wonderland", "What Lies Beneath", "Cast Away", "The Polar Express" & "Beowulf") is excellent!

This is an excellent telling of Charles Dickens' novel and one of the best telling of Scrooge's story ever made as a movie. This is another motion-capture hit for Zemeckis. Jim Carrey is impressive in 8 roles that were given to him by Zemeckis.

When you see Jim Carrey portraying a lot of characters in a movie, you get excited because you know the potential he has when creativity is allowed (The Mask, for example). Unfortunately, this movie doesn't take advantage of their star. As a matter of fact, practically anyone could have played the roles he was given with the same excitement.

The effects here are amazing, and the computer animation is wonderful. Their treatment of Marley's Ghost is by far the best of any Christmas Carol movie I've seen. It's actually scary, which is good. However, Jim's performance as Scrooge and the ghosts seems basically phoned in. He's playing the characters pretty much standard as any other version of the film. His interpretation of the Ghost of Christmas Past is actually the weakest I've seen (their decision for his overall design was strange anyway). This is one time they probably would have come off better to just let him play Scrooge and give the ghosts to someone else. Gary Oldham does a great job as Cratchit and Marley, actually stealing the show from Carrey's generic Scrooge.

Don't get me wrong, I wasn't expecting Scrooge to play like Ace Ventura or anything, but it would have been nice to see a little spark of fun in there somewhere. It seemed to me that Carrey was actually bored with the roles (since this was motion captured from him).

Still, it's nice to see "A Christmas Carol" on screen again. This is pretty much a fairly standard version of the story and probably won't be considered "must see" for the holiday season after this year (like "It's a Wonderful Life" or even other versions of "Christmas Carol"), but it was nice to see the 3D take on it.

I saw A Christmas Carol today at the new IMAX theater at the local AMC 24. While the screen was a little smaller than the IMAX theater I went to in the past, the less confined seating was much more relaxing and picture quality seemed to be even better. Seeing this in digital 3-D is the only way to go. This story has been told a million times before and while it's still a great one, I felt a little bored at times. I miss the days when Robert Zemeckis made films with real actors on the screen, not just the animated versions of them. I will admit that it has come a long way since The Polar Express, but those eyes still have a creepy dead look to them. Jim Carrey is very restrained, especially for him, and made a Scrooge to remember. He also plays The Ghost of Christmas Past and Present. This film is way too scary for kids. I know if I was little and saw this, I wouldn't sleep for nights. It's weird that they released this just one week after Halloween, but if you want to get in the Christmas spirit way too early, this is a very faithful adaptation of the Charles Dickens classic.

...Sometimes creepy even. Ask the ghost of Christmas past.

Going in, I wondered what this latest version of a Christmas Carol would have to offer, to differentiate itself from other versions. Songs? Crazy characters? Turns out that a lot of the fun here is the 3-D. The ariel view  throughout becomes like a ride through the streets of Jolly old England, circa 1836. Horse and buggys, street beggars, dogs... cool stuff. Zemekis pays close attention to details throughout, giving us a great sense of the dark, dismal, and the cold.

Perfect set up for the widest array of ghostly scenes I think I've ever experienced in another Christmas Carol. Including Scrooge being chased around by a roaring Death Cab. Around Stave IV.

I have a feeling that Zemekis may have lifted a few one-liners from Mr. Magoos 1962 opus version, but other than that, he follows the book very tightly, and offers a unique interpretation of the story. He still hasn't figured out how to CGI the eyes straight entirely in his work, but he puts this sqiff to use, in characters like Marleys Ghost, who does a neat trick with his eyes in one scene... oh yeah, and when he unties his jaw.. hillarious!

I'm a big fan of a lot of Christmas Carols in general so I can't say its the best version I've ever seen; But this is a top shelf experience... see it in 3-D, so you can enjoy "the ride."

As a fan of Charles Dickens (not only the Christmas Carol but all his works) I was very excited to see a new rendition of this Christmas classic.  I had high expectations with Jim Carrey performing Scrooge and the ghosts and I am very happy to say, I was not disappointed.  I won't clutter this review with much detail about the story, afterall, we all know it.

The look of the movie in 3D is absolutely wonderful.  3D is either a success or a disappointment and in this film it's a success in my opinion.  It looks amazing, it's not just some doctored scenes with items pointing out at you...it's a full environmental experience.  The movie in its entirety is visually stunning.

The story is very well told, it starts just as the book begins with Scrooge signing Marley's death certificate and unlike many renditions there is no narration through out..the story unfolds before your eyes and is told through the characters.  Jim Carrey is wonderful as the ghosts and Scrooge, in some instances I wouldn't even have realized it was his voice if I hadn't already known it.  Gary Oldman voices Bob Cratchit, that was a nice surprise.

The ghosts travels with Scrooge were the best that I've seen and the most visually stunning, they do have an advantage with it not being live action and this also adds an appeal for younger children, making this rendition fit for the entire family. This story really is about hope and change and the "magic" of Christmas.  Robert Zemekis did a wonderful job here and he definately deserves a nod for understanding what this story is about.

Also one more note: we got to see a 3D preview of the new movie Avatar and three other upcoming films, so make sure you arrive early, there are several previews in 3D that are exciting to see as well, so don't miss them waiting in line for popcorn.

This film is a great way to start your holiday season.  So as Tiny Tim observed...God Bless Us, Everyone!

This animated adaptation of Charles Dickens', "A Christmas Carol," could well become the classic film version to 21st century kids as the Alistair Sims "Scrooge" became in the 1950s.  The animation is so 19th century authentic that it actually is continually illustrating the Victorian classic book.  It is true to the Dickens words and spirit.  From the beginning it is a visual-experiencing of olde London.  All that is missing is the smell of coal smoke and horse dung.

It is not just Jim Carrey (Scrooge, 3 ghosts, & more) and Gary Oldman (Cratchit, Marley, Tiny Tim) that so passionately do the unforgettable characters' voices. Colin Firth, a necessary for any top quality Victorian London story, as Ebenezer's nephew Fred's voice, is animated to look the most like himself.

Animated sets are thrilling and punctuated with moments like sliding down hilly iced-over cobblestone back streets, the coal soot patina on 1840s shops, and animated London fog looking more atmospheric than the real thing. Scrooge's bony fingers are as true-to-life as on an emaciated elderly man near death. Scrooge is himself a bit ghostly; like a more aged Lemony Snicket. And about as darkly evil.
____(Excuse the name dropping, but with any great film--it is bound to be compared to other accomplishments.) Like the aerial flight through time where Scrooge is hand-held by a ghost.  It recalls images of Mary Martin in "Peter Pan."

The 2nd 'Scottish' Spirit's home was a Victorian Christmas visual masterpiece of delight; and the trip through Christmas Present, more like floating with "Mary Poppins."  Spirit of the Future's trip adventure, however, depicted more peril than anything "Indiana Jones" ever encountered. Action! Misadventure! Fear!

This film is technically animated beyond "Polar Express."  Characters' hair, snow & ice, and the Cratchit Christmas goose are all as aesthetically fine and real as any photography.

The only negative for this adaptation to Dickens' Christmas Spirits' story is the inability to push a "play" button on a remote for a second viewing. I can't wait for a DVD version (next year?). For now, it's back to the box office.

IT'S A CLASSIC-both book and film.  Don't do this Christmas without seeing it.  It's perfect for our economic times: the underlying theme that Christmas is about giving and family.  Take your family (as long as the kids are beyond 2nd grade). Preschoolers and early-elementary age might be frightened.  Remember the Dickens story is a bit on the dark side till the end.

Don't leave till after the credits.  The song sung by Andrea Bocelli, "God Bless Us Everyone", (writers: Alan Silvestri, Glen Ballard) is at the end.  It could/SHOULD be on this year's Top-10 Christmas Song list.  Hear the words--they summarize the meaning of the story of Ebenezer.

Anyone know, is that song on a CD yet?
READ COMMENTS. A CD IS AVAILABLE BY BOCELLI WITH "GOD BLESS US EVERYONE".

I went to the midnight show of Disney's 'A Christmas Carol' last night and going into it, I was really excited. I was lucky enough to see the train tour that went around the country to promote the film and even got to see director Robert Zemeckis talk about the film at the D23 Expo. I'm a big fan of the Charles Dickens story as well, of course my two favorite film versions star Kermit the Frog and Mickey Mouse.

Disney's new motion capture film is wonderful! I absolutely loved it, and I'm usually not a fan of motion capture. Jim Carrey is fabulous as Scrooge and the three ghosts. This adaptation is more faithful to the Charles Dickens classic than any other film version. In fact, it even begins with the opening of the book. And I found the 3D to be more impressive than Disney's previous 3D releases. In this film, items appear to pop off the screen and into the theater.

Overall, I loved this new version and will definitely see it again in theaters. However, I must warn anybody with small children that this film is scary. In fact, it made me jump twice. I have to say that my favorite film version is still 'The Muppet Christmas Carol,' mainly because it's fun and has a lighter tone, but this new version is very good. This is sure to become an annual tradition for families to watch every holiday season.

Jim "the Mask/Pet Detective" Carrey stars as Ebenezer Scrooge, as well as the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Yet-to-Come!

Gary "Bram Stoker's Dracula" Oldman as Bob Cratchit, Jacob Marley and Tiny Tim!

For IMAX!

Featuring a half dozen dancers such as Becca "'Tropic Thunder' Go Go Dancer/'Not Another Teen Movie'/'Starsky & Hutch' Cheerleader" Sweitzer, how could this not be the best version of "A Christmas Carol" yet?

It was Number 1 the first weekend it opened, November 6, 2009.  Sign up at Amazon.com to be notified via e-mail when it becomes available on DVD; I did!
I thought it was well done

Jim Carrey.  Jim Carrey.  Jim Carrey.  Dude is talented and also a little weird and the weirdness factor is increased by the mo-cap pixelated likeness.  But despite the ability of the CGI to do more visually to make this more magical it actually feels less magical because the other side characters are not realized in important ways.  The focus and love and attention is so much on Carrey's CGI looks and mo-cap performance that they lost the heart of this film and it loses its footing.  For this movie, despite it dealing with ghosts and visions, is best when it is extremely grounded in the emotions of the characters.  And the unreality of the CGI simply detracts from those emotional elements.  It's not Carrey's fault.  The movie is a close-up focus of Scrooge and that's what they do but there's too much pandering to him and too little development of the other characters and they don't draw out his redemption long enough.  I think that every version of this Christmas and literary classic has been better.  2.75 stars.
Great classic Christmas movie!! One of our go to movies at Christmas

This movie was so boring and slowly paced that I did not finish watching it. I think kids, especially, would be bored out of their minds watching a movie like this. I would have rated it 1 star. HOWEVER, it does have a couple of redeeming qualities:

#1) I thought Jim Carey's acting was fantastic. He embodied Scrooge really well.
#2) The animation is beautiful and sometimes even lifelike.

So, for the good acting and lovely visuals, I'll toss in an extra star.

We like Tim Burton and Nightmare Before Christmas, but this animation is very real and very creepy/morbid. The ghost are visually haunting. I felt they went too far and it really compromised rather than supported the story. Unfortunatley, we were looking for a good Christmas Carol film to watch with the kids--this wasn't it.

Just saw it now and  is certainly the best version of A Christmas Carol ever. Majestic, dark, thrilling, compelling, and with an ever powerful social message.
Scrooge a cold-hearted and tightfisted miser. He despises all that brings joy and comfort and above all denies social responsibility for the less fortunate in society. After sending away his nephew and spurning his Christmas dinner invitation and after turning dwon a request from some people from a benevolent society for a charitable donation (He says 'Are there not workhouses, are there not prison?' - arguments used by modern libertarians)  He is terrorized by the ghost of his deceased business partner Jacob Marley.
Suitably scary haunting scenes with Marley and the arrival of the ghosts. Tear jerking moments like the  feared death of Tiny Tim.and the full atmosphere created, highlights include the majestic force of the Ghost of Christmas Present , and the message of the spirits of want and of ignorance reminding Scrooge of his own cruelty. This version will have you hooked.
This was a great version to keep both adult and teenage interest for a classic story.
The animation is pretty cool. A classic, must see movie for the holiday.
I couldn't watch it. Playback quality was terrible.

My review is not of the content of the film, but the sound mixing on this purchase from Amazon video. My Samsung TV is a 2015 model with volume levels from 0-100. I rarely have to put the volume louder than 20-25 to hear any TV show or film adequately. I had to turn this all the way up to 80 to hear it worth a damn, and then, whenever a moment of loudness like his visit with Marley or his argument with Belle or when the Ghost of Christmas Past rockets him into the atmosphere, I have to turn the volume down by 40 notches to avoid the sound traveling to other rooms in my house.

I'm not certain if this a problem unique to the Amazon Video format of this film or the film studio's mixing of the film, but it's a pretty miserable watching experience, either way. Really disappointed that I paid money to purchase this film to watch with my family during the holidays only for it to be a crappy experience.

If you like it, more power to you.  Let me know and you can have my copy.

Filled with beautiful dialogue straight out of Dickens, voices are well cast and characters well designed, but poor cinematography and drawn out flying/chasing scenes prove distracting, and like other motion capture movies the characters all seem to be stiff-moving with faces and eyes lacking emotion.

A Christmas Carol has always been my favorite holiday movie. Ive seen every version of this story and I absolutely adore them all. This one, however, is a personal favorite. It moves along briskly, but its beautiful and I do love the creepy factor. Those complaining about how its darker in its telling, baffles me. I mean, the storyline of this story has always been dark as to leave a everlasting impact on the viewer (and in its original case, impact the reader). This is a gem, and totally underrated. The acting is superb, and the animation is another unique way of retelling this classic and always relevant Christmas tale.

Scrooge is rendered superbly well, a la' Jim Carrey.  Watching this on Blu-ray is top notch visual experience, it must be seen with Blu-ray to get the total effect.  Easily one of my favorite Disney films of all time.

A Christmas Carol is one of my favorite holiday films and I own several versions of it. Disney does an impressive job with the tale, but I believe the idea of a 3D film got the best of them. First off, I am not a fan of 3D, I find it more of a distraction than an asset. There are a few films that really benefit from the process, but they are few and far between.

Many scenes are set up for 3D in this version so when watching the standard version some small scene seem a little odd. Not enough to hurt the film any, but it was noticeable to me. Disney's stays pretty faithful to the original story, but strays a bit too much towards the end. I don't mind some embellishments to breath some life into the story for children, but I found the last chase sequence to be overkill. It would have worked better to shorten the chase and lengthen the ending which seemed too abrupt. For me, Scrooges change of heart is the most inspiring event in the entire story, but in Disney's version' we never see the Cratchit family's reaction to Scrooges sudden generosity, he doesn't stop by to give Mr. Cratchit his raise or vista with Tiny Tim and the family.

The film is also a bit scary for young children, not that this is anything new for Disney, they have been giving kids nightmares ever since Snow White, Pinocchio, Bambi and Dumbo. My point is, if you're going to scare the kiddies, then at least have a little longer redemption in the ending.  Overall i really enjoyed this version and I can see me watching it during the holiday season as an alternate to the many version I own. The Blu Ray looks fabulous and the bonus material is very interesting and extensive. If you're a fan of this film, but the Blu Ray, if you're into 3D I would imagine it is very impressive.

First I will start by saying that I never give spoilers in any of my movie reviews. I keep it simple and say whether it is good or not.

I purchased this movie mainly just to add another 3D title to my movie collection. So needless to say, I had it for quite a while before ever viewing it. But now, after viewing this movie, I wish I had watched it sooner! I found the movie very well done. The story line was entrancing and at times a real treat. I would consider this to be a great movie for the entire family, although the very young ones at around 6 or younger might find it a little frightful at times. Also I must add, this movie would be enjoyable any time of the year!
 The 3D aspect was done very well. I have seen better but by no means was this done poor. There where a few times when the 3D was a little underwhelming, and I may have noticed a slight ghosting here and there (notice the pun there ;) LOL) But all in all a pretty decent 3D rendering is what you can expect. Please keep on mind that not all 3D Televisions are made the same and some 3D TV's just aren't very good at rendering decent 3D. Luckily we have one of the good 3D TV's. So when a great 3D movie is played on our television, it is a very special treat, as we can expect it to play just about as good as the theatre can provide us. I have a large collection of 3D films and have viewed most of them, so please trust my advice when I say that this particular 3D movie is a good one.

I will sum this review up with this advice. If you are at all on the fence about whether you should buy this movie or not, I would suggest you do, and enjoy it.

Not a bad version! Adheres very closely to Dickens, with a few homages to earlier movie versions.

The only negative was the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come part. There was a rather long scene with Scrooge being chased by a hearse. It dragged on endlessly and had little value to the story. Also, at the end of this scene, Scrooge shrinks down to about six inches tall and talks in a squeaky voice. Christmas Carol meets the Borrowers? I think not!

A bit darker than some versions. The Ghost of Christmas Present actually dies at the end of his scene and turns into a skeleton that decays to dust. Ignorance and Want grow up into a young thug and an insane prostitute. A good extrapolation of what Dickens was trying to say with these symbols, but a bit lurid and possibly upsetting to children (if any happen to be watching).

Overall, a great new take on an old classic. Next to Patrick Stewart's version, which is incredible, I'd say it's right up there with the best.

The 3D is excellent.  It was done in the same way as Avatar and the Polar Express.  Actors motions were digitized and then they were clothed in animated skins, so there are no glitches common in 3D conversions.  The result is a very realistic 3D animation.  My only reservation is that this is a bit over the top.  The chase scene and moon shot were added for the gee-whiz effect.  The chase scene would be much too scary for young children.  They claimed that they could achieve effects that were not in the original Dickens.  Actually they added effects that were definitely not in the original.  For example Scrooge did not fall backwards flat when confronted by Marely's face on the knocker.  However the flying scene with the ghost of Christmas past is quite in keeping with the original story.  If they had omitted some of the over the top additions, they could have included things like the Ghost of Christmas present visiting miners and adding savor to the dinners of the poor.  Jim Carey not only acted Scrooge, but also the three ghosts!

It will not replace the more accurate Alastair Sim version. Now if we could have an accurate 3D version with a strong flavor of the original drawings, that would be wonderful.  I did like the depiction of the Ghost of Christmas future, but I would have preferred Scrooge clutching him and having him turn into the bed curtains, rather than tumbling Scrooge.  The ides of having Scrooge travel looking through the floor of his room was very nice, but it kept the ghost and Scrooge a bit distant from the action.  So the ghost could not sprinkle the food of the poor.

Of the many interpretations of Charles Dickens "The Christmas Carol", DIsney's is the most faithful to the original. From the very start you see that the movie is in the same time period as the book. Along with the time period, nearly all of the movie's characters fit Dicken's descriptions perfectly. From Scrooge who was described as a 'cold hearted man who speaks in a shrewd voice and despises Christmas." To the ghost of Christmas present who Dickens described as," a "Jolly Giant" with dark brown curls. He wears a fur lined coat and a holy wreath." Along with the descriptions of characters, the movie has a nearly identical story as the novel. From the introduction, to the Spirits' visitsit seems that Disney took some real inspiration from the original novel. Another detail that stayed exactly the same was Scrooge's character arc, from grumpy geezer to a jolly,giddy school boy. However there was one main difference, which was the expansion of the Third Spirits' visit. Originally, in the book Scrooge visits a old london pawnshop where some of Scrooge's colleagues try to sell his old posessions and later on the Third Spirit shows Scrooge his grave in the near future. However, in the movie Disney includes these scenes but adds more. Including Bob Cratchit and Scrooge's nephew's reaction to Scrooge's death. I think the movie's expansions increased Scrooge's character depth since it shows him how other people would react when he died and when he saw how happy his nephew was to see him die. This and the gravestone were the pushing point for Scrooge that finally made him want to change. In conclusion, Disney stayed faithful to Dickens' original work with several quotes, character descriptions/arcs and similar scenes. However the largest difference between the movie and the novel was the expansion of the Third Spirits' visit which increases the volume of Scrooge's transformation.

This is one of the better movie adaptations of A Christmas Carol as it says very true to the original by Charles Dickens while still adding a nice touch here and there. The dialogue is nearly perfect, it is almost as if Jim Carry (the voice of Scrooge) was reading from the story and not a script. Other minor things such as the church bells in the background are all there as well. The plot is also very close to the original with a few touches like (spoilers) when tiny Scrooge is being chased by the third spirit riding on a black carriage or scenes that are drawn out to add atmosphere or just lengthen the movie.

Some scenes may be scary for small children such as the ghost of Marley when his jaw hangs loosely from his mouth (although this is brief and afterward the ghost then moves it up and down to talk in a comedic way). Also, the ghost of Christmas yet to come could be frightening as he looks like the grim reaper and is definitely intended to be scary. Overall, I would say 7-9 years old depending on the kids maturity would be a good age to watch this.

Is it a good movie? Yes, I would say it was a good movie maybe a little too scary for kids and overall has a sad atmosphere until the end which I thought was nice and cheery. My favorite ghost was definitely the first as I thought that ghost was most true to the original story and very close to what I imaged while reading the story. My biggest complaint is the lack of character Jim Carey gives Scrooge and that Scrooge doesn't seem to change quite as much throughout the movie as he does in Dickens original story.

The movie was great! It was possibly the best representation of the story yet. It almost perfected the line between being dark ( to represent Scrooges point of view) and still staying very christmas like. It was just like the original story with many quotes from the book appearing in the movie. Such as Scrooges partner in business Marley being "dead as a door nail" and many other quotes said by the christmas spirits. They also represented the spirits exactly as how i imagined them in the book especially the spirit of christmas present with the book describing him as a very large and jolly man wearing a large robe and the movie did just that! All in all this is the best representation of the story by far and keeping the stories feel intactl.

It is a great movie!  It is very similar to the book and quotes many things from Charles Dickens, A Christmas Carol.  It is about Ebenezer Scrooge, who it a very rich man, but hates spending any money.  He also dislikes Christmas and hates watching everyone else being merry during the holiday season.  On Christmas Eve, Scrooge is visited by the ghost ofhis dead business partner, Jacob Marley.  Later that night, Scrooge is visited by three ghosts of Christmas: past, present, and yet to come.  The ghosts shows Scrooge many things and the more he sees the more he feel happy and also worried about the future.  Once the ghosts are gone, it is Christmas day and Scrooge realizes what he has to do to change the future.  The movie has the exact same plot as the book.  I feel that there could have been more things from the book instead of the long horse chase with the ghost of Christmas yet to come, I also felt that there was to much flying around with the ghosts.  The movie was very good at showing Scrooge slowly change from being a mean and lonely person to a joyful and happy one.  There are some parts that aren't in the book at all, like when Scrooge shrinks while he is with the ghost of yet to come, it is still a good movie though.  Even though it's supposed to be a ghost story, it may be a little scary for families with younger children.

This is a very good movie but be warned that small children may be frightened or mildly scarred. The ghosts are represented in both very dark and light ways, although, mostly dark and quite disturbing. I liked how it represented the original carol by Charles dickens. The representation was adequate and the message clearly given. Also, the characterization of scrooge was excellent.

As others have noted, the most glaring shortfall with this video is the extremely low sound volume.  I watched on my notebook, first with built-in speakers, then with wireless earphones, and then with an amplified external speaker near my ear.  The only way I could finally catch all of the dialog and phrases was to use the subtitles along with the audio.  I find that flaw a real shame, because the rest of the experience of this video is exceptional.  I almost never purchase videos, but after seeing this one on a televised broadcast a couple Christmas' ago, I have wanted to experience it again but never located another broadcast of it.  Finally, this Christmas, I gave up and just bought it.  I am not a movie critic, so can't assess the various technical criticisms of the film, but I can say that I find the "motion capture animation" technique extremely appealing--providing an ideal mix between pure film and animation to give a development to characters and backgrounds that can't be achieved with direct filming, and yet the sense of realism that that is not present with pure animation.  The overall result (in my opinion) is a tremendous 5-star video experience which must regretfully be reduced because of the flaw with the audio.

I loved Polar Express and am a great devotee of Christmas Carol (must have seen the George C Scott version close to 100 times), so I wanted to give this a chance. But unfortunately, this has to be the absolute worst version I have ever seen. Someone, they managed to turn a Christmas story into a hybrid of action/adventure and horror movie, complete with chases and gratuitous violence. What is missing is the soul of the story, which is about love for one another and our world, redemption, and the meaning of Christmas.

If I had never read the book or seen any other versions, I really would be lost and not have a real clue what this story was about. There was so much missing from it, and all of the warmth has been sucked out of the story. I am amazed to see so many 5 star reviews--so I have to wonder, are these people who just like special effects and find movies like Christmas Carol boring without them? Is this a reflection of the amount of violence in our movies in general, so people are okay with Scrooge getting tossed around, chased at full speed by phantom horses (the Victorian version of a car chase), dropped from space and crashing into the floor, battered around, etc---all things that have nothing whatsoever to do with the story? The ghosts were all somewhat violent, and almost everything that happened had some degree of a "chase" or scaring Scrooge, or was just downright macabre. These extra scenes and add ons came at the expense of cutting out important parts of the story and developing it. The ghosts don't come to scare Scrooge, they come to allow him to revisit his life and see how he turned into the bitter man that he is, and they show him hope of redemption. He changes not because he was bullied or terrified into it, but because he sees what he has lost and that there is still time to change. But in this version, that is precisely what happens--he is attacked, chased, bullied, terrified--over and over and over--until it becomes downright idiotic. The is a beautiful classic story, and while parts of the original novella are dark, it does not need special effects. Or violence. Or spirits turning into skeletons. Or any of this other nonsense done to heighten the "entertainment" value.

Overall, this movie just seems like an effort by the producers to show off their animation technology, and appeal to the video game crowd, because that's what this reminded me of. We stopped it about 3/4 way through, after Scrooge is being chased by horse drawn hearse through London, and then shrinks to about 6 inches in height, goes flying through the sewers, and then takes a roller coaster ride on an icicle--just what Dickens had in mind. Fortunately, we didn't waste any money purchasing this.

Also a warning--this is not a movie to show to young children. The ghost scenes are really over the top, and will scare children.

This may be the first thing (other than The Mask) that I could tolerate Jim Carrey beyond five minutes. Indeed, had I not seen his name on the credits I would not have known. So props to him. I loved Zemeckis' efforts with The Polar Express so really looked forward to this one. The style he used carried over, quite well I think. And, parents be warned. This isn't Disney's Muppet Christmas carol. It is much darker, and could be scary to some. Indeed, it honors, somewhat, Dickens' subititle that this is a ghost story. What disappointed me was that a great opportunity was missed to present the entire story. If so, it might have rivaled the 1951 B&W classic with Alistar Sims as Scrooge. Instead, it was edited and in the edits, they left out one of the greatest bits in which Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Past visit Fezziwig's establishment. After watching Fezziwig and his family and employees (including a young Scrooge) make merry, taking on Scrooge's attitude, the spirit scoffs at the waste of money. As Dickens wrote:
"A small matter," said the Ghost, "to make these silly folks so full of gratitude."
"Small!" echoed Scrooge.
The Spirit signed to him to listen to the two apprentices, who were pouring out their hearts in praise of Fezziwig: and when he had done so, said,
"Why! Is it not! He has spent but a few pounds of your mortal money: three or four perhaps. Is that so much that he deserves this praise?"
"It isn't that," said Scrooge, heated by the remark, and speaking unconsciously like his former, not his latter, self. "It isn't that, Spirit. He has the power to render us happy or unhappy; to make our service light or burdensome; a pleasure or a toil. Say that his power lies in words and looks; in things so slight and insignificant that it is impossible to add and count them up: what then? The happiness he gives, is quite as great as if it cost a fortune."
There is so much truth there in the power of kindness, and especially in our own society today post-election (and during). Indeed, organizational leaders might draw a lot from taking Scrooge's comments on Fezziwig to heart.  Yet---for some reason that part of the carol was omitted. Dickens' use of Fezziwig's kindness toward others was juxtaposed against Scrooge's hard-heartedness to clearly contrast the two outlooks that, at least to me, it weakens the rationale for repentance at the end when Scrooge learns the name on the tombstone.
As a result, the best I can give it is "it's OK." A golden opportunity was missed here.

To those reviewers who panned this movie because it was not suitable for children to watch should keep in mind that Dickens did not intend the story for  small children in the first place. Not being a huge fan of Jim Carrey or animated versions of this wonderful, ADULT story, I did not expect to like this very much. I am happy to say that I was quite wrong. While I do agree with some of the reviews that mentioned the long, drawn-out "chase scene" with the hearse (made to make the 3D fans happy, I'm sure), overall, this was a wonderful version of the story, ranking right up there with the ones starring Alistair Sim and George C. Scott (my all-time favorite). Jim Carrey was amazing as Scrooge and several other characters, proving to me that he doesn't always have to be a caricature of Jerry Lewis. The special effects were amazing, and the Spirits were downright terrifying at times - just as they should be.  Marley's Ghost was jaw-droppingly frightening (pun intended).  The Ghost of Christmas Past was both wistful and eerie, and the Ghost of Christmas Present was totally faithful to Dickens' description of him. His "demise" was one of the most powerful images of the movie. As another reviewer mentioned, I appreciated the film's depiction of the future that awaited the children Greed and Want. Finally, The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come was absolutely terrifying, a horrific shadow of Scrooge's future. This movie depicted 19th century England just as Dickens wanted us to see it - full of inequality, greed, want, poverty, and tragedy. "A Christmas Carol" was Dickens' warning to society to take heed of its actions during the Industrial Revolution - and this movie stays true to that purpose. No, I wouldn't let small children watch this - but for teens and adults, it should be a Christmas staple.

What a piece of garbage! Completely devoid of any real Dickens. I can't believe I rented this BS. Hands down the worst Christmas Carol  I have ever seen. Whoever came up with this idea should have been shot at dawn. Ohhh Walt if you could only see what they've done, you'd probably roll over in your grave. This piece of crap is blasphemy to the author and the true meaning  of the writers intent. If I could have given it a minus 5 stars I would have in a second without hesitation.

In this day and age of cult classics and good bad movies getting more recognition than ever, its hard to really remember what exactly a bad movie is. In my opinion something like Plan 9 from Outer Space really isn't all that bad a movie. If people are still talking about it and showing it to others over fifty years later, it really cannot be all that bad.

In my opinion, a truly bad movie is a film that is bland and mediocre, like local microwavable frozen pizza from a gas station. Truly bad films can be films that are just being pumped out in the hopes who raking in a lot of money. In my eyes, they just to be films only horny teenagers unable to pay attention to the screen cannot consider a waste of their time.

Nothing inspires films like this to be made more than the holiday season. When you turn on the television and see some generic rom-com with the whitest people imaginable kissing in red sweaters as a generic Christmas song with a lot of bells begins to play in the background, it really makes you want to cancel Christmas and just celebrate Halloween for the second time this year.

One of the films that can easily go into this category is Disneys most recent rendition of A Christmas Carol.

To me, its very baffling that anybody would take a story that is regularly performed on stage and turn it into this over-bloated CGI animated movie that has a budget somewhere around 175-200 million dollars. As a fan of film, it is very infuriating to watch this movie knowing how much it costed and thinking of how many actual good films that couldve been made with all that money as I watch this animated film that already looks cheap and outdated seven years after being made.

The cast involved with this film is supreme and impressive, and its a shame that you have to watch them doing voice-overs for these lifeless computer drawings instead of actually performing it in front of a camera.

A big part of A Christmas Carol is watching Scrooges redemption at the end, the audience happily watching as this cold heartless man is transformed into someone with a new wind for the bright side of life. Due to the CGI animation, this transformation never really happens. Since the focus was on using the best technology imaginable and not focusing on the emotion behind Scrooges transformation, the Ebenezer Scrooge in this version feels just as cold and lifeless in the end as he does in the beginning, no matter what he says and does.
The best way to sum this version of A Christmas Carol up is that theres just something that feels very wrong about a story with themes revolving around poverty and greed being turned into this overpriced animated movie that was in a 3-D format when released to make even more cash.

A film such as this is lucky its a holiday film, because without stations needing a Christmas film to fill airtime, there is absolutely no way this movie would ever be watched after 2009.

I first saw this film when it was still in the theaters and when I came out, I thought "It was disappointing to me." I first saw the Christmas Carol from the 30s when I was 5 and I loved it! Then, a couple years later, I was introduced with a video called "Mickey's Christmas Carol" and I admit I still love it. Now, I'm pretty much grown out of it I was pretty excited to see that a brand-new Christmas Carol movie was coming out. Yet, I was expecting it to be pretty funny and to be kind of a fun thrill ride. Then, when I went to the theater, I thought, "Oh, I'll like it" but I got bored in the middle. Obviously, the movie is NOTHING like a plain comedy or even action-adventure film. No, it turned out to be quite a thriller like the other Christmas Carol films, but I still thought it was kinda funny and somewhat fun.

Today, I saw this on STARZ and I seemed to have liked it a little better than before, but was still a horrible let-down for me. I guess I have grown out of a Christmas Carol, but I heard a lot of critical acclaims for this film and how it was well-received, but I know I'm not the only one who thought this film was embarrassing and generic. Well, you know, I could say that the visuals were nice, the script was flat, and some of the characters and even the ghosts were annoying. Yeah, I didn't like it at all very much.

The first thing I thought last year when Disney's A
Christmas Carol hit the screen was "Do we really need
yet another retelling of this story?"

It's easy to give Robert Zemeckis a break on selecting
this material for his capture performance animation.  What
he has created a is a very faithful retelling of the story that
takes place in a very lifelike animated world that is greatly
enhanced by 3D technology.

I sit and wonder who Zemeckis was making this film for.
Under the Disney banner, you would think that this would
be a "family-friendly" film.  However, this retelling is very
dark with very disturbing imagery and dialogue that comes
directly out of the book.  For me this was the downfall of
the film.  I could sit here and appreciate the fact that the
director didn't pander to young audiences but at the same
time I found that the film comes off as being somewhat
dull with very little emotion.  It's a wonderfully animated
film but I get the feeling that I'll be sticking with the more
uplifting classic versions for years to come.

Disney has struck gold with their first 3D digital release.
When you combine such wonderfully detailed animation
with 3D technology that really conveys a sense of depth
you have the perfect disc to demo to your family and friends.

There are wonderful 3D moments to savor here such as
the falling snow that often comes within inches of your
face.  The most bizarre sequence in the film is when
Scrooge shrinks in size.  I really disliked the fact that
the filmmakers went in this direction but I can see why....
it provides some of the best 3D moments in the film due
to its varying height perspectives.

Alas, the transfer is not perfect.  There is ghosting here,
and I think I have figured it all out.  For me, I find ghosting
in any dark scene that is lit by ambient light.  Pretty much
every 3D transfer I have seen suffers from this problem.
Some worse than others.

In the first 10 minutes as various characters assemble
in Scrooge's darkened shop lit only by candlelight, you can
see varying amounts of ghosting.  Take a look at the dance
sequence of Christmas Past at the 41 minute mark where
the camera pulls into Scrooge and Belle.  Belle's facial
features are clearly doubled.  The home of Bob Cratchit,
also very dark, provides ghosting problems.  Look when
Tiny Tim raises his cup and exclaims, "God Bless us all!"
You can see that the cup looks doubled.  When the Ghost
of Christmas Future brings Scrooge back to the Cratchit
home and we watch a heartbroken Bob climbing the stairs
you can see ghosting.  Fortunately, these ghosting issues
are far more minimal than what I saw on The Polar Express.

I wouldn't say that there is much "In You' Face" moments
here, but the animation does make good use of having
objects protrude the screen without seeming like its going
for the gimmick.  Objects like snow, flame embers and
pointing fingers seemingly drift out of the display screen.

Presented in DTS-HD 5.1, I found the audio to be very
immersive featuring the score of Alan Silvestri combined
with a swirling amount of effect noises that cross every
channel such as the laughter of ghosts, the "whooshing"
of wind or the clapping of thunder.  There is an incredible
amount of bass to be heard here.  Turn the audio up as
Marley approaches from outside Scrooge's bed chamber.
I advise the same for when the Ghost of Christmas
Present opens the floor of Scrooge's living room and
begins shifting the house in different directions. You can
really feel the floors shake.

CONCLUSION

You know, I should never have gone with a
number rating system.  There is already arguments as
to why I would give a top-rating of "5" to a 3D transfer
that has ghosting problems.

The reason is because this format is still in its infancy
and either the hardware or the studios can't get all the
kinks out that cause problems like ghosting.  So, sometimes
I have to put something that can't be easily be solved to
the side and look at the bigger picture.

I am ranking Disney's A Christmas Carol as one of the

Ok, so I avoided yet another Disney "A Christmas Carol" with comedian Jim Carrey as the role of Scrooge when it came out.  I am not a giant fan of this style of animation either.  However, I purchased the movie on the recommendation of a friend and was blown away!  Aside from the animation, this version is the closest to the actual novel that I have seen.  I actually opened up a copy of the book and found that the dialog was 80% accurate or better.  The animation is really good and you can easily see the actor's personality through the animation.  The effects were marvelous and seemed to capture the intent of Dickens' descriptions.  Wow!  A new favorite.

I enjoyed the movie quite a bit, watching it in 3D. This movie was made for 3D viewing, and you would lose some of the effectiveness of the movie if you watch it in 2D. The animation is amazingly detailed and lovely, the characters and action engaging. Note two things, though:

- This is a serious story with horror undertones, it's a ghost story with Christmas themes. It's very tasteful, but it's definitely too scary for small kids.
- This takes the Charles Dickens story quite literally, including the dialog. I couldn't understand 70% of the dialog because of a combination of the English accent and the ornate, 19th century English that the characters spoke in. Next time I watch it, I'll turn on the subtitles, and I suggest you do the same.

This was a well-made film, and entertaining. However, I felt the emphasis on entertainment distracted from the true message of the story. There was far too much fantasy inserted, and in my opinion, too much liberty taken in creative license. After recently reading this with my children, we were inspired to watch a movie version. Instead of fully enjoying this together, I found myself apologizing for all the frightening scenes (that were NOT in the book). Most of all, it felt like the message communicated was that scare-mongering can lead to a repentant spirit...not true. We can not be scared into long term change for the good. Charles Dickens understood that, and I believe he would have been disappointed in Disney's presentation of his story.

I normally don't like Jim Carrey, but he does do a good Scrooge. The CGI is so realistic. It is noticeably darker and more intense than the George C. Scott and Patrick Stewart versions. I was surprised that, like Tom Hanks in The Polar Express, Jim Carrey does multiple voices in this movie.

This has become my favorite version of this story.  I'm wishy washy about my rating and thought about giving it 5 stars, however I just couldn't due to some slight shortcomings.  I love how the movie starts and the scenery they depict.  I think the atmosphere is about as close to the book as any film could have or has come.  Finally this version got the feel of the ghosts right.  I love the Jacob Marley depiction and all three ghosts.  In particular I like the Ghost of Christmas Past.  He finally made sense.  The other versions I've seen have made lame attempts to capture the spirit of this Ghost, but in my opinion have failed.  I like how the Ghost of Christmas Present stays in the same room, but makes it transparent to see the world around them.  The Ghost of Christmas Future was equally good and I loved how they portrayed him more as a shadow.  But I don't see as much of this ghost, or the future, as I wanted.  They get too wrapped up in the carriage chase and we don't see as much of the future as we want or as is in the book.  This is one of the shortcomings.  Some other shortcomings, are that pieces are left out here and there and some parts breezed through too quickly.  This is probably due to trying to keep the movie a bit shorter, perhaps for the kiddies, which I'm assuming they were marketing this movie for.  I wish this movie was extended and included all the parts, which seem significant, to me.  It is not what one may expect for a Disney type movie, being overly silly or childlike, but portrays some of the darker parts of this story pretty well.  In the end, I really enjoy this version more than any other and look forward to it each year.  I just wanted a little more out of it.

Charles Dickens is an author whose works deserve to be read. He was taken from his parents as a boy, and forced to live in a 'work-house' to pay-off his family's debt. So he knows all-too-well of what he writes. This version of Christmas Carol is visually true to the book in many ways that other versions previously could not be, largely because of new technology. The voices and even faces are provided by a tremendous collection of very well-known celebrities from the U.S. and the U.K. Allan Silvestri weaves traditional Christmas music through his own work of inspired genius,
and the result is a combination of all parts of this story that most seem to remember ~PLUS~ several surprises that will make you go and pick-up
the book to see what you forgot, or missed. Bob Zemekis is an inspired genius of the film industry. He wants to entertain the entire family and always remembers them when he creates films like this one. It is a Christian parable, a joyful one, with a warning to the hard-hearted. It is MAGIC.

As for the purchase, it was smooth as silk and delivery was speedy, and the product arrived in perfect condition.

As for the movie, it isn't my cup of tea, but the recipient loves it and was thrilled to receive it as an early Christmas gift.  It is a version of Charles Dickens's "A Christmas Carol," and is visually very interesting, though even as an adult, I find it a bit creepy and not very Christmas-y (oddly, I don't feel the same about other interpretations of the classic, or even "Scrooged").  This movie includes several ghosts (shown as more frightening than in the cartoon version Disney made in, I believe, the 80's, so just because your kids love that, don't assume this is similar) and has a few moments that may frighten children under about 8, so parents, exercise caution when deciding whether to show this to your kids.

POTENTIAL SPOILER BELOW (on the off chance you are unfamiliar with the story)...

This story is essentially the same as the classic, with Scrooge being visited by his deceased business partner (whom we see, dead, in the opening scene), Marley.  Marley cautions Scrooge he must change his ways or, basically, be damned in hell.  He advises him the ghosts of Christmas Past, Present, and Future will visit him.  The ghosts visit, he eventually sees the error of his ways, and he repents.  It has been years since I read the novel so I may be mistaken, but I don't believe the book includes things such as Scrooge becoming an actual rat, running around in the sewer and underneath buildings, and I don't recall his maid stealing his clothing, though I again may be mistaken.

Overall, some people (including the recipient who watched it easily a dozen times in the two or so weeks between receiving it and Christmas) love this version, but I find it oddly unsettling in a way I have never before felt about other versions.  I recommend you borrow it from the library or watch it on tv before purchasing it, in case you feel as I do.

The only thing that bothered me was actually the special features. In the "making of" featurette, they have this college professor touting how faithful this version is. She lists a few examples of things from the book that are in this movie, but none of them are actually in the book! For example, she talking about Stooge getting chased through the streets of London by a couch, and being shot up toward the moon. Neither of these things are in the novella. I think if you are a literally professor you should get your facts straight, especially if on camera.

Most of us already know the storyline so no surprises there. However, the animation was amazing. I don't know if I'd recommend this for very young children as I thought the spirit visitations were pretty "dark" and a bit intense. But for older kids and adults I would say watch it. The life lessons are always good reminders of what is important.

This is a movie I REALLY wanted to like.  As the movie started, I was very impressed by the quality of the animation, the careful adherence to the dialog of the original book, and in particular, the characterization of Scrooge by Jim Carey, who does an amazing job of emulating the performance of the great Alistair Sim from the 1950s version.  During the portions of the movie where the human characters interact, it's beautifully done.  When the supernatural characters are introduced, the movie goes totally off the rails.  Rather than maintaining the film's beautiful subtlety, exaggeration reins supreme, and  wild action sequences turn the whole thing into a spiraling video game.  The producers also go way beyond the book in the degree of vulgar horror portrayed.  Dicken's original has its dark moments, but in this movie, the encounter with Marley's Ghost, and the death of the Ghost of Christmas Present contain scenes that are absolutely gut-wrenching.  It's a sad commentary on our modern culture that movie producers think it necessary to add insane, frenetic action sequences that have no connection to the original story, and horror movie death scenes, in order to hold the audience's attention.

Watched this version on television tonight because a family member recommended it. It did have much of the dialogue found in Dickens' story. If they'd stuck to that, it probably wouldn't have been bad for an animated movie. However, the screaming door knocker, the comic presentation of Marley's ghost (although probably frightening to some smaller children), the rocketing of Scrooge to the moon when he caps the Ghost of Christmas Past, the Ghost of Christmas Present turning into a laughing skeleton, that ludicrous chase with the red-eyed horses and Scrooge turning into the incredible shrinking man, all meant that while I might have watched it once, I won't be doing so again and I certainly will not add it to my collection of Christmas Carol movies, even if Jim Carrey did do a respectable imitation of Alistair Sim and sounded very Scrooge-like. I would have given it only one star, but since it's better than the travesty directed by Jason Figgis, I'm giving it two.

This version is different any other version of Charles Dickens's classic story that you have ever seen, how it is different you ask this movie was made using motion capture allowing actors to play more then one part. There has been many film versions of a Christmas Carol, and I hope that this will really be the last, I mean how can you make another film version having making one with motion capture. Jim Carrey stars in this film version where he plays Ebenezer Scrooge, and all 3 of the Christmas spirits. The movie opens with that opens, and revels that Jacob Marley was dead to begin with, and then you see Ebenezer Scrooge (Jin Carrey) speaks the first lines of the movie where he sees the corpse of his dead partner, and signs his death certificate, and soon he makes his way through London as the opening credits are seen, all the way to the counting house, where he enters. Then 7 Christmas Eves later, is where we get to the main action of the movie, where again we see Scrooge in his counting house and his employee Bob Cratchit (Gary Oldman)  where his nephew and only living relative Fred (Colin Firth) pays him a visit where he invites him to Christmas dinner, but Scrooge refuses, and saying that Christmas is a humbug. He also a visit with collectors looking for donations, he turns them down saying he only supports the prisons, and the workhouses, and that anybody that would rather die had better do it. And he has them leave with no donation made, and keeps Bob working hard and paying him little money, and even to beg for a day off to spend Christmas Day with his family. He grants his wish and tells him to be earlier the next day. Scrooge returns home where he lives alone until his late partner Jacob Marley visits with chains, and warns Scrooge of what is to come if he doesn't change his ways, and that he will be haunted by 3 more spirits. This is where I leave you, watch this movie to see what happens. Stay tuned during the end credits to hear Andrea Bocelli sing God Bless Us Everyone the only song in the movie, but I would also like to warn that this movie is rated PG for parents that might want to get this movie for kids, to watch this movie with them.

Zemeckis seems to be having so much fun playing with the freedoms that digital storymaking allows that he forgets that just because something can be done doesn't mean it should be done.

A new season, a new holiday, and just in time for Christmas, a new re-telling of the Charles Dickens
novel, A Christmas Carol.
The book is one of the most filmed adaptations of all time; there have been over 60 film and TV
productions of A Christmas Carol. Personally, my two favorites have always been Scrooged with Bill
Murrary, and The Muppet Christmas Carol. There are not many ways to improve upon the Dickens book,
but I think one way is to add Muppets.
On Christmas Eve, Ebenezer Scrooge is visited by three spirits, plus his dead partner Jacob Marley, who
show Scrooge just how much life has to offer. He is warned to change his ways, or be doomed for all
time. Jim Carrey plays Scrooge (and several other parts). Carrey has always been a versatile actor, but he
really shines in this role. And as directed by Robert Zemeckis, the other big star of this re-telling is the
performance capture animation.
First introduced in The Polar Express, and then last years Beowulf, performance capture allows an actor
to dictate how an animated character moves and behaves. Actors wear a computerized suit to perform
their role, and can then be placed into any setting. The technology has been getting better with each film,
and the use of it here is beautiful. I would try to see this on the big screen for the animation, if for nothing
else.
One of the things I like best in this re-telling is that Carrey, because of the animation, also plays the roles
of the 3 spirits. Essentially, Scrooges own sub-conscience takes him on this journey. For the first time,
we can see how this story could all be in Scrooges head, and that only he has the power to change
himself.
I recommend this film to everyone, though I think kids could be scared by some sequences. Dealing with
ghosts, even during the holiday season, can be a frightening experience for anyone.

I like it quite a bit. I would have given 4.5 stars but it wasn't an option. It's creepy, in a good way, lol. The animation is really astounding and the best I've seen. I love the story, and only in animation is there every freedom to create what your vision is. I liked that there was a bit of story left after he awoke still alive on Christmas day. Most of the time, the story just ends there. Jim Carrey did an excellent job, and my only deduction of 1/2 a star was because I thought the voice on the first ghost was a bit weird and forced sounding, and the second ghost just couldn't stop laughing for some strange reason. I didn't get the symbolism there. Marley's ghost flapping his own jaw was weird too, lol. But overall, the movie was very enjoyable, a bit creepy, and also very Charles Dickens come to life. I have watched only the 2D version. I can see that there were some scenes that were clearly designed for 3D but it doesn't take away from the standard version.

This version is very true to the Dickens book, the pacing is good and the animation look like the actors that are doing the voices. the only drawback is Disney takes over at one point and goes crazy with frantic chase scenes etc. Jim Carrey is restrained in this version, so you don't have to worry about a reprise of that terrible Grinch portrayal.

I've seen most of the Christmas Carol television and movie versions that exist, and I usually end up watching many of them every year at some point -- a Christmas tradition I suppose! I had heard mixed things about this one, but I decided to give it a shot.
My biggest issue was I had trouble feeling any "warmth" from the movie. The characters weren't fleshed out very well, with the exception of Scrooge. It almost seemed like the dialogue and story was rushed a bit so we could see Scrooge get chased around or fly through the air some more. Jim Carrey did an admirable job as the old miser, but I had trouble feeling any connection with anyone else. Scrooge's nephew Fred seemed a bit more like an old school televangelist regarding Christmas than someone who truly cared for his uncle, Bob Cratchit seems to get very little screen time compared to other versions, and the visual style of everything was a rather big hindrance to me.
Frankly, even though the technology has obviously improved since the Polar Express days, I actually think the character design for this motion capture stuff was a bit worse. Realistic with a strange caricature edge... The characters didn't always have the emotion in their faces that I think would have improved the scene. A few times it felt like an older video game cutscene to me. However, the scenery was another matter. Even though Zemeckis tried his hardest to milk the 3D for all it was worth and turn everything into a chase or flying scene, digital England looked very sharp.

My biggest issue though, was with the ghosts. First things first, Marley would have made me wet my pants if I was a little kid. Granted, I was a pretty easily startled child, but I know lots of children are. Fair warning: they will hate this movie if they don't like scary/sudden things.  It was definitely one of the more intense Marley scenes around, and judging by the previews, I would not have guessed it was that dark in a movie seemingly targeted at families. Nevertheless, it was effective. I wouldn't have slept after that if I was Scrooge either.
The Ghost of Christmas Past was one of the most annoying and baffling takes on that character I've ever seen. I'm glad they included the cap in this version, but I would have used it a whole lot sooner on him. A combination of creepy, hard to understand, and just plain weird for the sake of weird.
The Ghost of Christmas Present was better, but why..did..he...have..to laugh... incessantly? It was so forced and annoying, but it was still a welcome change after the Ghost of Christmas Past. Once again things took a dark turn toward the end of his time, with the spirit's aging turning to the gruesome, and ignorance/want getting a little embellishment. But, I'm glad they kept the aging in there! It's an interesting part of the story to be sure.
The Ghost of Christmas Future was actually very creative and fresh. Other than the ridiculously long chase scene thrown in for no good reason, I enjoyed this part of the movie the most. Again, a bit creepy, but it's actually supposed to be. It was well done and eerie, without too many cheap "jumps".

All in all, it was alright. I'll stick to the George C. Scott version for a more serious and accurate tone, The Muppets for silly, Patrick Stewart for Patrick Stewart, and Albert Finney for the "artistic liberties" version of the Christmas Carol. All of those have heart and a good human element to them...something I found very much lacking in this one.

I have been a long-time fan of the classic Dickens ghost story, A Christmas Carol and can say that after having seen this for the first time in 2012, it has become one of my favorites. ONE of my favorites, I must add - as all of the different versions have their own strengths and peculiar faithfulness to, or departures from, the original.

I have in my collection most of the theatrical versions of this story. Reginald Owen, Alistair Sim, George C. Scott, Patrick Stewart, and now the Disney version. Interestingly, I find (at least in my opinion) this version is one of the most faithful of all of the versions to the original Dickens novel as far as the dialog and scene-setting goes. Notwithstanding, the modest comedic license and the gratuitous "in your face" scenes that take advantage of the 3D capabilities of this release, the overall heart, dialog, and message of the original story come through with powerful and lasting impact.

I must admit, I have never been much a fan of Jim Carrey's work to date, but this movie says much to me about an actor who would take part in a project such as this and deliver an outstanding performance - visually, a digitally rendered work nonetheless, but his vocal performance is delivered with such feeling and power that makes one forget it is an animated telling of this classic story.

There are a number of sequences in this version of A CHRISTMAS CAROL that owe everything to Disney and naught to Dickens. These scenes occur most especially during the meeting with the Ghost of Christmas Future wherein Scrooge turns into the Incredible Shrinking Man for no apparent reason and thereby becomes, for all intents and purposes, nothing but a cartoon character. The way too-long chase by the ghostly coach and demonic horses is another excessive instance, reminiscent of Disney's Headless Horseman chasing Ichabod Crane. Another underwhelming because it is too overwhelming moment is where Scrooge rides the cone of the Ghost of Christmas Past like a rocket to the moon. These scenes come near to destroying the meaning and the message of Dickens' "Ghost Story of Christmas." Near - but thankfully not near enough.

Of course, the reason for these Disneyisms is clear: the makers of this version need to keep the attention of child viewers alert and action-happy. If I'd previewed these moments only I would have bet the entire movie was nothing but idiotic action.  Gladly it is NOT - and what remains is something quite fine and mostly faithful to its source material.

This is a very artistic film, rich in period detail, by turns intimate (such as the scenes spent with the Cratchit family) and panoramic (as in the flights through the streets of London and through Time and Space).  It is absolutely incredible how vocal and bodily performances by actual actors can be transmuted by the magic of computers into, well, a living cartoon without its actually being a cartoon.  The idea of motion capture goes back to Max Fleischer who patented the idea of the Rotoscope in order to simplify the process of animating movement by tracing frames of live action film. Fleischer utilized this process in the SUPERMAN cartoons of the early forties - and in the full-length cartoon of GULLIVER'S TRAVELS.  Technology has since then made a quantum leap with computerized motion capture - and the results are awesome and evocative.

This is an age of excess and over-the-topness in current films.  Like kids playing with new toys, many of our filmmakers don't know when to stop with the thrills of computer wizardry. This movie literally dies when it is trying too-hard to be most lively. Luckily, one can be an editor by way of fast forwarding through the inanities! Also luckily, the pluses of Disney's A CHRISTMAS CAROL outweigh the negatives.  This is a version of the classic tale that the entire family can enjoy.  The Ghosts are, yes, scary - but by keeping so much of the original dialog and main themes of the original novel this is a version that can be both entertaining and educational to anyone - children of all ages! - not familiar with Dickens' actual tale.  Recommended - if only to see Scrooge take the coins off the dead Marley's eyes lest they be sealed in the coffin and thereby wasted according to Scrooge's rapacious worldview.

At first I was turned off by bad reviews from friends and my general dislike of the author and the story, but one of my students convinced me to preview it for him and I couldn't have been more surprised by the outcome. It really is worth the time!
