This is a really scary movie, with the best sound track of Christmas music I ever heard.  It's pushing out other versions to become my current favorite.  It's funny, too, and attention holding.  It's hard to stay quiet while watching this because I want to shout and cheer and scream and gasp.  The color and animation are brilliant.
This is pretty true to the original story, but a little frightening at times. My kids ages 6-13 enjoyed it.

I think this is an excellent Christmas movie for adults and older children who do not get scared easily. I personally enjoyed it very much, especially the beautiful music, fantastic visual effects, and the fun ending. One of the Christmas movies which give a wonderful sense of a joyful, sincere conversion of heart.

But the huge downside of this movie is that it is not suitable for young children, and even many older children and adults may find certain scenes highly unpleasant. It has scenes which are very scary, dark, and gruesome. In one scene, probably the creepiest scene I have ever seen in a family movie, you watch a man dramatically age and turn into a skeleton over the course of about a minute while he is shouting and laughing maniacally.

I have no idea how on earth the creators thought these terrifying scenes would be loved by children. Who OK'd this?

One of the aspects I love about the movie is how close it stays to the book, but it exaggerates the scary parts. The book itself has some dark and scary parts, but the movie actually exaggerates and prolongs these, as well as adding some of its own. It would have been much better for it to tone these parts down considerably, make them more comical and less dark, and instead emphasize the happy parts, especially the ending.

There are a couple lines from the book which the movie changes to tone down religious elements (though the movie is filled with religious music and some religious imagery), and one line which is changed into an explicit critique of "men of the cloth". This is just another way the creators shot themselves in the foot here, because this line is sure to offend many religious people while attracting few others. Religious sentiment aside, I think it is a silly diversion which awkwardly distracts from the otherwise memorable scene.

This is a movie I will continue to personally enjoy myself, but I will never show it to children under about age 10.

We enjoyed this one last year on pay per view and wanted to add it to our DVD collection.  On a flat screen, all the visual tricks used to enhance a 3D experience seem a bit contrived, but like the effects in The Polar Express, the story still takes center stage.  In some ways, Robert Zemeckis misses the point of this Christmas story and in an effort to make this film an "experience" for 3D theater viewers, especially children, he sacrifices story and character for cheap amusement park thrill ride.  In A Christmas Carol, the story still comes through and many elements of the original story appear that are often not included in other film versions of this story.  Unlike the Polar Express, the music in this film is nowhere near as memorable.

it's a good film with impressive animation.  My 9-year-old son found it scary, and it was significantly darker in tone than many of the previous adaptations.  There were sometimes additional unnecessary sequences interposed in order to show off the animation.  My biggest complaint was the unevenness of the volume.  The dialog was so quiet that I had to turn the volume up very high to hear it (I have no hearing issues), but then if there was any music or sound effects, those were incredibly loud.

"...There'll be scary ghost stories. And tales of the glories of Christmases long, long ago." It seems a rather British tradition that Christmas time be accompanied by scary tales and ghost stories. Some of that tradition has drifted over, and trickled down, to this side of the pond, here in the good ole US of A, and perhaps the most well-known incarnate manifestation of that tradition is in Charles Dicken's classic "A Christmas Carol" (the original title of which was "A Christmas Carol. In Prose. Being a Ghost Story of Christmas.") and its many adaptations on film and stage. This particular adaptation of Robert Zemeckis' holds true to the scarier and darker aspects of the Dickensian story, probably more than any version I have ever seen. Purists and fans of the book who appreciate British Christmas pastimes will probably love that part. Idle American moviegoers thinking that it will be light, feel-good Disney fare will likely be a bit taken aback by it. I might as well get this out of the way -- is it the best adaptation of the story? In my opinion, no. The 1951 version A Christmas Carol (2012 release) starring Alastair Sim is the most moving and has the best character development. You see so much more of Scrooge's backstory in that version -- more of his transition from being a warm, young idealist in love with a good woman to someone who fears the world too much and seeks emotional shelter in cold hard facts and becomes bent and hardened by them; the reasons of WHY he hated his nephew (Scrooge's sister, Fanny, died giving birth to Fred), why he often struggled with self-esteem and perhaps became reclusive (his father was unkind and didn't want him around, because he blamed Ebenezer for his mother's death, which of course wasn't his fault, just as Fanny's death wasn't Fred's fault), -- and so we can empathize with Scrooge more; he becomes more human. He becomes the best kind of villain, one in which we see our own darkness, fears, and shortcomings reflected in him. This Disney version falls short of that beautiful backstory, and I struggled to give it five stars for these reasons (almost went with four), but it triumphs in other areas: First, of all, it's a Zemeckis film, and that means a solid, glorious production from start to finish. The wintry scenes are so realistic and beautiful. There are so many themes of a classic Zemeckis flick -- flying, time travel, and of course, the amazing music composed by Alan Silvestri, which also includes some BEAUTIFUL, elegant, soaring arrangements of some traditional Christmas hymns. Second, the three ghosts are marvelous, all played by Jim Carrey, which is to me a symbolic self-projection of Scrooge's past, present, and (tentative) future Christmases. The Ghost of Christmas past, especially, is bar none, the most creative and artistic interpretation of that timeless, mysterious character. If you have not seen it, I don't want to spoil it -- but the effect of that character for me, was reciprocal of the form and shape he takes -- "luciferous", in the best, most angelic sense possible. The animation is superb. The 19th century London-era conditions and Christmas decorations are invitingly real. Scrooge's harsh features and coldness of personalty are well-depicted, as are the youthful joys he later displays, post-redemption. The animation is of course, more advanced than Zemeckis' earlier "Polar Express". All in all, though not the best adaptation in my opinion, it's still a great movie, a great escape into Dickens and beautiful Christmas artistry. For those who enjoyed the ghostly British traditions of this version, and would like to see something similar, I'd recommend the first episode of the second season of "Lark Rise to Candleford" Episode 1 [HD]. (I always like to include similar products in my reviews for those who share my same interests, and hope you find that helpful.)

I've seen five other versions of the Christmas Carol including: The Muppets, George C. Scott, Mickey's Christmas Carol, one with a London Humbug, and Mr. Magoo's version.

The reason for my rating on this one: 1 star for animation. 1 star for voice acting. -3 stars for the scary images.

I felt like I was walking through Transylvania at Christmas time. I've never been a fan of creepy things and this reminded me why.

Major Spoilers below:

It opens with Marley laying in his coffin. I felt that was a new way to do it, but I've got to admit, I hated it. The last thing I want to do is look at a dead man. I didn't mind Scrooge going through the streets and seeing how others avoided him. But once the ghost of Marley entered the scene, rolled his eyeballs around in his skull and flapped his ripped jaw, I was feeling freaked out. My first thought was: I'm never letting my kids see this movie!

When we get to the ghost of C. Past I was surprised to see a ghost that resembled a candle stick. When he spoke, he sounded like a hissing flame. I couldn't see his face very well (granted he was fire, but still I wanted to see more definition). I didn't like him.

C. Present started out well enough, I liked his throaty laugh. But his "end" was too much for me. I always preferred the fading out, shine, or sparkle effect to let the viewers know he was leaving. In this one he literally has a heart attack and DIES! He becomes a laughing skeleton! O_O!!! Then Ignorance and Want (the kids under the robes) spring up and turn into a knifing thug who's caged and then a prostitute who gets straight-jacketed and drug off screaming into the dark. If I'd been a kid, I would've ducked behind a couch!

C. Future. He was the one I expected to be scary and I definitely wasn't disappointed. But the carriage chase scene...not needed. I'm pretty sure they only stuck it in for the 3D thing they were doing at the theaters.

Overall, there wasn't enough of that warmth or happiness that you get in the other films when you watch the Crachetts, Nephew Fred, or the Fezzwigs celebrate their Christmases. I needed more of the family love and kindness, the joyful feel of celebration going on in order to care about them. Instead, I found myself very distanced in order to be mentally shielded from any another deteriorating ghost that might pop up in the movie. I couldn't even get a feel for Tiny-Tim. I felt for Bob when he went up the stairs, but that's about it.

There were three swears during the film, not needed.

When Scrooge came to himself, I was happy the film was nearly at it's end. When it was over, my mind was still reeling over the laughing skull of Christmas Present. I couldn't get that terrifying image out of my head.

I've read the Christmas Carol many times and it is my favorite traditional Christmas movie.  For those who do not know, the story is about the redemption of a man so heartless that drastic measures have to be taken.

However, the measures taken in this movie are too drastic.  It should have been rated PG-13.  In short, they destroyed the wonderful beginning.  The film had promise, but it didn't keep that promise.  I wish I had Red-Boxed it first.

I give the talented voice-actors a solid 5.
The animation a solid 4 - because sometimes Scrooge looked wall-eyed or cross-eyed.
The script gets no stars and Disney a -6 for stamping their approval on a vastly inferior production.

Below are spoilers, but a few reasons I can't give this film a better rating.

Marley's lower jaw became unhitched during his famous rant and he had to manipulate it to speak.  Macabre and bizarre.  All previous versions of Marley had at least stirred some empathy from me, but not this one.  I liked his long chains and locked trunks better than him.

The ghost from Christmas past was a flame-headed alien with an unpleasantly sinister voice. If you read the book, you will find the ghost looked human - most of the time, not like a wandering candle.  This was never my favorite ghost, but at least the ghost showed more human qualities in the other productions.

The second is usually my favorite ghost.  What isn't to love?  He looks like and laughs like Father Christmas.  However, in this version, the ghost has a heart-attack, complete with gripping his chest and moaning in pain.  He turns chalk-white and dies in front of Scrooge - disintegrating into a laughing skeleton while the twins of ignorance and want become, respectively, a criminal and a screaming lunatic (literally).

The last ghost, the one that everyone should expect to be creepy, finally fits the bill and they did a great job with him.  BUT they added a long drawn-out chase scene involving red-eyed horses that chase an ever shrinking-in-size Scrooge who then speaks like someone that's been sucking helium.  Here, the film became a confusing collage of Sleepy Hollow and Darby O' Gill meet Scrooge!

At the end, where Scrooge is cavorting around, lightened of his decades-old burden of acknowledging the miracle he's been given, the cleaning woman freaks out and swears.  It wasn't needed and it wasn't funny.  There were no warm fuzzy feelings for me at the end.  I did not rejoice for Scrooge because it fell far short of my expectations.  I say save your money and time, don't bother with this one - watch the one with George C Scott as Scrooge.
Even though the special effects were great, they changed the storyline too much - much more darker, and violent than any other Christmas Carol.

I have always enjoyed the story of A Christmas Carol, and I love (traditional hand drawn) animation. This obviously is computer animation and the animation is incredible. However, I was rather disappointed in this version of A Christmas Carol.  To me, it seemed to drag quite a bit to where I was losing interest. (VERY unusual for me!)  The Ghost of Christmas Past was a bit weird, in looks and in speech. I'm not quite sure what effect they were going for here but it did not work for me.  And I'm still trying to figure out why Scrooge was shrunk down to rodent size wtth the Ghost of Christmas past. (Maybe I missed something while I was losing interest as it dragged.)

I'm glad I didn't spend too much for the DVD. As much as I enjoy watching (repeatedly) the different versions of A Christmas Carol (and other Christmas movies), this is one I won't be watching over and over. I had heard good things about it but again, was rather disappointed.

Are they deliberately trying to kill 3D?  To get a 3D Blu-Ray format of this movie you have to pay for a Blu-Ray format, a Blu-Ray 3D format, and an E-Copy.  It is no wonder it costs $31.49.  And it seems to be that way across the board on most of the 3D movies worth watching.  Just give us the option to purchase what we want, a copy of the movies in Blu-Ray 3D format.  Now that the technology is up and running it doesn't cost any more to produce it in 3D than in 2D.  Enough of the BS!

The 2 Stars rating was because of all the BS.  The movie was excellant and on its own would have been given 4 Stars.  The sound affects especially were great.  The ticking sound made by the sleet impacting the roof tops was right on.

I would rather have given this 3 1/2 stars.....4 seems like a little too much but 3 seems too little.  If you are a Jim Carrey fan then, of course, rent/purchase this version.  If you've never seen a production of this classic tale...what the heck are you waiting for?!  It provides a VERY important lesson....one I wish the world would remember a little more often!

My personal favorite version, however, remains Bill Murray's turn in "Scrooged".  I'll admit I haven't seen it in awhile but if I'm remembering correctly, it's funnier.  This version (Jim Carrey) has some dark moments (I know, they all do especially when it comes to the Ghost of Christmas Future) so keep this in mind if you have younger viewers.  In fact, for the younger set, I recommend The Muppets Christmas Carol as a better introduction.  Older kids and tweens will probably prefer Disney's a Christmas Carol to the Muppet version however.

Please note...I did NOT view this in 3D...I'm sure the effects were cool though.
A nice animated spin on a great story about the holiday season... My kids and I watched this and had a great time enjoying this movie... A+

I love any thing Jim Carey plays in anyway. This is an awesome version of The Christmas Carol. Recommended for the whole family for a night of fun and popcorn. Anything you purchase from Amazon always has great bargains and ships out quickly. I couldn't be more pleased than I am with Amazon and of course this wonderful movie.
I didn't think I would like this as much as I did having seen the old classic so many times but after watching it I was pleasantly surprised and would watch it again.

A great version of the classic story. Visually and story wise extremly well done. It is on our short list of required viewing for Christmas every year. A great gift for other families......
My students loved it, it had a great message. The only problem was that some of the scenes were too dark and hard to see.

(A Note to parents:  This movie is rated PG for scary images.  The images are not gratuitous or 'above and beyond' the story line.  My 10 yr old watched it without any trouble.  You know your kid, I recommend previewing if you have any doubts, or check out the parent review on IMDb. They do a great job outlining movies specifically for parents.)
What do you get when you put Jim Carey, Gary Oldman and  Colin Firth in a Robert Zemechis  movie?  A great movie!  This classic story has been updated with  Zemechis' animation technique while staying true to the story.  There are some rather dark elements that I think Dickens himself would approve of.  Carey and Oldman deliver their multiple characters beautifully.  I find it ironic that Carey, who usually plays a character that makes us laugh (Mask) plays Scrooge and the 3 Ghosts, while Oldman, who usually plays the bad guy (Sirius Black, Sid Viscous, Dracula..to name a few of his brilliantly delivered bad guys..) plays Tiiny Tim, Bob Cratchet and Jacob Marley (we couldn't have all these crazy characters without giving Oldman one bad guy, could we?)  There are some scenes at are a bit darker that we are used to.  I think Zemechis had the courage to show the story as the dark story that it really is instead of trying to 'pretty it up' as has been done with previous versions.  My 10 year old son has watched it without any trouble.  If you have a child that is sensitive to dark images, you might want to preview it first...then decide.
Ordered this right before Christmas and didn't think it would arrive in time for Christmas but to my surprise it did and made a great stoking stuffer.
We enjoyed watching this movie which teaches some valuable lessons while having cool effects.  Some parts are a scary for younger (< 7 yrs) viewers but its a great story overall.
Great animation that makes the Christmas Carol a modern must have classic. Fast and easy transaction, makes a classic more enjoyable for the younger generation.

I bought this to show my 5th graders after reading Dicken's original book together.  I was very pleased that most of the dialogue as well as the rest of the movie was identical to the book with some creative liscense taken in the final scene where Scrooge meets his final spirit.  All in all, very well done without being over the top Jim Carey.
I saw this on TV and we really enjoyed it.  I think they did a great job making it and it seems to stick to the book.

It's seems to be set in the "theatrical size" which won't allow adjustment to full letter-box size on some DVDs.  That said, I'm still very HAPPY I bought the movie and can enjoy it all year long at our convenience.  Worth the price paid.

Terrible! I purchased brand new/wrapped in original wrapping so it would be nice & the cover was broken and ripped but someone wrapped it in plastic wrap. Very deceiving.

This is the only other version of A Christmas Carol I have seen other than the Muppet Christmas Carol. This version is wonderfully made. Well animated and a great retelling of the classic Christmas story. A treat for the children. A must see for adults wishing to return to the joys of their youth.

Disney's 2009 version of "A Christmas Carol" brings Charles Dickens' classic to vivid life with the dramatic animation over live acting that made "Polar Express" such an entrancing visual experience.  In the case of "A Christmas Carol", the effects are quite moving.  Londontown never looked so forbiding in the dark, nor so cheerful on Christmas morning.  The ghosts look as scary as they were meant to be; after all, "A Christmas Carol" is about motivating a stubborn old miser into better behavior.  The movie effectively captures all the essential elements of the story, including the presentations by the ghosts of past, present, and future.  If some scenes are a bit over the top, such as the exotic dancing at Old Fezziwig's, or Ebenezer's flying sequences, it's a bit of relief after Scrooge's unhappy confrontations with the ghosts.  Jiim Carrey does a terrific job behind the animation as Scrooge.  Highly recommended, as long as you like this particular style of animation.

I didn't really care for the animation syle in this movie. I feel like I just spent the last two hours on a cartoon camera flying through the air.
Jim Careys voice acting was sub par as well.

Most know the story so no surprise there and it was told in generally the same fashion as most other versions. The animation is what made this version different. The scenes were amazing but the faces have that weird almost too realistic look to them. All in all a great holiday classic although it may be a little too intense for very young viewers.
I swear that the topic of the item requested should be the only KIND of item that you see.  In this case a DVD and I received A DVD  thank you

We rented this on Redbox and the movie skipped...through the whole movie, but it wasn't scratched or visibly damaged in any way.  Then my boyfriend bought it for my kids for Christmas...the brand new one skipped in the exact same way - also not scratched or damaged in any way.  Is it possible that Disney had a problem with production???  My kids are really disappointed...AGAIN!  I would not buy another one until they recall all the bad lots.

This version is as true to the book as any other version. One scene in this movie that is missing from all the other versions is the scene of the ghosts flying through the air, and the changing face of the Ghost of Christmas Present. Although Jim Carrey has been known to over-act, he treated this work very seriously. He plays many parts, which is not apparent at all. The Ghost of Christmas Present is rich in detail and color; the way he and Scrooge peer into the present is closely follows the book. Many civic virtues are demonstrated in this work. A+.
I think this is a great movie for yourself and your family to watch together.  It brings back the real meaning of Christmas.  Loved it.  Saw it in 3D at the movies and it was even better.

This rendering of A Christmas Carol is amazing: intense, humorous, thoughtful, heart wrenching, whimsical, and even a little creepy at times. . .just about everything you could ask for. thought it was A Liltle bit scary for the young ones and Probably would not see again but worth it watching once.

However, this time, the volume was recorded so low that my students could hardly hear the movie, even through the surround speakers. We read the play, and I was so excited to show this to my students. For ten dollars, I felt very cheated. The movie, itself, is great. Jim Carrey always adds extra flavor to whatever he is in!

Scott version.  Please don't assume that because it is a Disney movie that it is appropriate for all ages if your children don't like to be scared.

As a reading specialist, I read the original story to my students and ask them to make mental images of the text to help with their understanding of the story.  I then use this version of A Christmas Carol to provide them with an opportunity to do a compare and contrast with someone else's interpretation of the text.  I found this version to do a good job of following the story line.

This movie does a good job of capturing the spirit of Dickens' story but has a couple too many unnecessary action sequences that don't really add anything to the story.  I guess they are there to keep kids from getting bored but for adults, they are just tedius.  Otherwise, I liked the movie and would recommend it.
I love the book and every version of the movie that have been made. If you haven't watched it yet, you should do so. You might learn something.

This is a pretty good movie. I hadn't seen it before this. The kids had seen the other "A CHRISTMAS CAROL" movies and they liked this one the best. I would recommend this movie for anyone who has children. It is an animated movie. If you want the kids to know what Christmas is all about let them watch this version of "A Christmas Carol".They will pay much closer attention to it. We now have all three versions. They are all good movies and make a terriffic collection.

I love A Chistmas Carol! But I regret ever deciding to watch this watch this movie over the weekend.  Although the film is beautiful, its also down-right scary!!  I'm almost 26, and this movie scared me to death.  I remember thinking, "Ok, if I keep watching this, it'll get better".  I was wrong, it only got worse.  When Jacob Marley's jaw broke I was shocked and horrified.  But that wasn't even the worst part.  The scariest part was when the ghost of christmas present was dying and decomposed into a skeleton with eyeballs in its skull, who was laughing hysterically.  This is NOT a kid's movie!!  If this scared me, an adult, I can only imagine how much it would scare a child.  I've had a hard time sleeping ever since watching this movie.  I have only one more thing to say to anyone brave enough to watch this movie.  Warning, this movie may cause you to become sleep-deprived due to nightmares, or because you're too scared to go to sleep; after seeing the horror that is Disney's A Christmas Carol.  Viewer beware.....

This is the worst version of "The Christmas Carol " I have ever seen. No seriously it really is. We rented it from Redbox first before buying thank goodness.  My kids ages 8 & 9 were horrified by the very scary to children scene's.  You can hardly understand the people talking so you have to listen very close which is very annoying. I suggest you watch it first to decide whether or not your children will be afraid or not. Oh and rent it before buying it & being stuck with it :)

It does have it's fun and silly moments (even though they are few and far between) but death is portrayed in a very real and serious way. I am a collector of the different versions of the Christmas Carol and this is one of my new favorites.  Although Patrick Stewart's version is the best for Purists, this one is a great story and told breathtakingly in animation.

I loved this movie. As a fan of this story, I have seen almost every version and read the original story and this is by far the best version ever made. The character animation is astounding. Its alive and detailed. The voice acting is top notch. Because the medium is computer generated they were able to add scenes from the book that are just not possible to include in any real acted version. It is as close to the book as you can get. I know some people see these CG movies and think they are for kids but you would be missing out if you skipped this over that thinking. This is just as dark and cruel if not more so that any other version made. This is one you will watch even if its not Christmas and you'll watch it again and again.
True to Dickens but SO much more!  I'm not a Jim Carrey fan but this movie is so well done, I can get past him.  Our new family favorite version!

Had I given this a single one-star rating, nobody would read my review thinking that I'm just a Disney-hater...but there's more to it than that.  True, the scene animation and voice characterizations are stellar.  But make no mistake, this is a HORROR MOVIE packaged as a PG children's movie.  Disney doesn't care one bit about all those children aged 2, 3, 4, 5, 6? etc who were dragged into the theater by their unwitting parent and exposed to some of the most horrific and startling images imaginable.  Why is Hollywood so hell-bent on hastening our children's transition from innocence to trauma-survivor??!!!  I can say that with some credibility as I am a therapist with trauma survivors...and there is such a thing as cumulative trauma.  This movie should have been rated at least PG-13, but Disney accomplished what they set out to do in creating a stunningly haunting adaptation.

Well done,scarier than I expected considering it is animation,but Disney always does a great job. One of my favorites and I have the book too,which is great. Also a great job by Jim Carrey. Love the creepy feeling throughout most of the show. Excellent special affects.

I thought this animated film was really quite remarkable, Carey was a lot more restrained than I thought he would be, he was very good. Many people have said it is too dark for children, I agree, even my teenager looked at me at one point, and said "This is wacked, can I go?" It just wasn't Muppets Christmas Carol - our forever Christmas Eve family tradition. She was disturbed. It was startling, actually, how gruesome it got. Spoiler alert - Ghost of Christmas present dies of what appears to be a massive heart attack, and then devolves into a skeleton that blows away like ash. The children in the folds of his coat reminded me of the apocalyptic stragglers from the Will Smith film, I Am Legend. It was in deed, really wacked. There is a carriage chase a little reminiscent of the Ghost of Sleepy Hollow, something not in the book, I think, and the end of that scene was very frightening. It really was too bad, would that the director has been as restrained as Carey - sometimes enough is just perfect. In spite of those things, or aside of them I suppose - I thought it was quite an accomplishment. The lovely bits were sublime.

And it really is a ghost story that isn't for children at all. It is a little surprising that the first big budget animated version of this story is also the scariest version ever filmed. Putting the Disney name before the title probably misled some into thinking this version was made especially for kids. I love the whole film but the part with the ghost of Christmas past is pure magic. If the scene with the shrunken Scrooge being chased through the streets by the black carriage seems out of place it's because it's not in the original story. Also the ghost of Christmas present dissolving into a skeleton is another new addition to the original. These things add thrills but they're not Dickens.

I'm a big fan of A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens. The story has become culturally iconic around the world.
It continues to resonate in our minds, since its original publication in the mid-1800's.
This production is, far-and-away, the very finest production of this classic story that has ever been produced,
and I have seen all of them.

The animation is so life-like... so very, very real ... so detailed.  Particularly because the storyline contains imagery
of ghosts sweeping Scrooge away on supernatural trips back and forth through time... it took the power of modern
animation to bring that to life.  This production offers us that which this story has always cried out for... such other-worldly
fantastic imagery... but not in a cartoonish way, rather, in a shockingly lifelike way unique to 21st Century high-end animation.

I was also pleased to see that so many of the best lines from the book are faithfully used in this production, and Disney did
not abuse its artistic license.  Disney (amazingly) also did not attempt to secularize or "de-Christianize" the message
at all. It packs the strong message of accountability and charitable responsibility, and does not shy away from that
Christ-centered message, or make it more "politically correct" in any way.

Visually, it is just spectacular. The animation is breathtaking in its detail (especially the BluRay version).
There are not many movies that I would watch over and over again. This is one of them.
If I could only have a half-dozen movies in my collection... this would be one of them.

The movie is excellent, it has a very good message. Some scenes can be frightening for kids but they are part of the story, I mean, those scenes appear in the book too. Anyway, I do not recommend it to very young kids.

I will never forget watching this movie for the first time in 3D at the theater. My eyes roved about the screen, trying to take in every minute detail - which was near to impossible. Some effects made me gasp and others made my jaw drop. Robert Zemeckis is one of my favorite film-makers simply due to his unique camera angles and approaches to scene setup. This movie satisfied me in every way. I left the theater with my mind whirring, still blown away by the entertainment. The thing I like most about Zemeckis' version is how he chose (unlike many other film-makers who have adapted Dickens' classic tale for the movie screen) to focus on the fact that the story really is, first and foremost, a haunting! Zemeckis' take on Dickens' story leaves viewers with less doubt of that fact than there should be doubt that Marley was as dead as a doornail!

To fully enjoy a movie the picture and sound are critical. This is especially true for Disney's, A Christmas Carol. I first saw this on IMAX in 3D and was very impressed. I later watched it on Netflix and enjoyed it, but the experience was not quite the same. While the story, animation, and voice acting were very good, much of the emotional impact of the story was lost at home without the engrossing effects of a six story three dimensional image and 10,000 watts of sound.

However, I recently purchased a 3D TV and decided to pick up this 3D blu-ray. After watching it with the surround cranked and the glasses on I found the experience to be close to that of the theater. One drawback was that the aspect ratio was set at 2.40:1, which is the standard for widescreen cinema. As a result, the "black bars" were present at the top and bottom of my tv. Normally I wouldn't mind this, but the IMAX screen ratio is 1.43:1, and so to fit the full IMAX image into a 16:9 tv the black bars should have been present on the sides of the screen. As a result, there were times where I felt that I wasn't seeing everything that I should have been, similar to watching a widescreen film that has been cropped to fit a 4:3 TV. I'm not sure what the film's optimum aspect ratio was intended to be, but I'm inclined to think that 2.40:1 is not it.

There are some original interpretations of the story and dialogue, and after reading some of A Christmas Carol, it seems to stay pretty true to the book. The chase scenes did get a little tiresome. I found myself wondering how much more screaming I could listen to, or how Jim Carrey managed to carry on like that in the studio. I think George C. Scott was a better Scrooge and other renditions took on a creepier interpretation that I thought worked better for the story, but this is a Disney film created in part for children, making it all the more appropriate.

Overall I'm very happy with this purchase, especially on blu-ray 3D. The story is timeless, the voice acting is very good, the music is phenomenal, and the 3D effects are awesome. I think that the 3D is critical to fully enjoy this movie, as it doesn't quite hold up on the animation, voice-acting, and action alone. If the image filled the TV or was set at an IMAX ratio I would be inclined to give this 5/5.
Obviously, someone learned (invented) some dazzling cgi techniques, and made a movie to play with them.  Some of the effects made me dizzy and nauseous.

In the Victorian era of the United Kingdom, the stingy and cranky Ebenezer Scrooge (Jim Carrey) that hates Christmas and people loses his partner Jacob Marley in a Christmas Eve. For seven years, he runs his business exploiting his employee Bob Cratchit (Gary Oldman) and spends a bitter treatment to his nephew and acquaintances. However, in the Christmas Eve, he is visited by the doomed ghost of the chained Marley that tells him that three spirits would visit him that night. The first one, the spirit of past Christmas, recalls his miserable youth; the spirit of the present Christmas shows him the poor situation of Bob's family; and the spirit of future Christmas shows his fate. Scrooge finds that life is good and God bless us everyone, changing his behavior toward Christmas, Bob, his nephew and people in general.

This dark adaptation of "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens to the screen is one of those optimistic films that follows the style of Frank Capra's "It's a Wonderful Life" and it is impossible not loving it. The redemption of the mean Ebenezer Scrooge in a Christmas Eve is one of the most known worldwide novels and this animation produced by Disney Company follows the style of Tim Burton and may not be the best adaptation to the cinema, but it is indeed effective and a good family entertainment. My vote is five.

I will start by saying that as a child, I performed in the live performance of "A Christmas Carol" in the local public theatre of my hometown for several years. In doing so, I saw the play many, many times.  This was the first movie adaptation of A Christmas Carol that I have even seen that evoked the deep, visceral feelings that I experienced as a child performing in the story.  The delivery of the lines, the almost imperceptible nuances of behavior at times, the atmosphere that came with each ghost... I haven't seen those in any of the other CC movies to date. This was the only one that I felt truly captured a live feeling, like I was immersed in the story instead of just watching it. In addition, the CGI allowed the ghost experience to go beyond what is physically possible in the constraints of the stage and turn into a true supernatural experience. I especially liked the ever-accelerating aging of the Ghost of Christmas Present. He only has one day to live in the novel as well, and this version really showed it well. The gritty yet romantic feeling of industrial, Victorian England was impeccably captured as well and and truly made me feel like I was there. The ONLY thing I didn't care for was the long chase scene. It wasn't true to the novel and went on for too long. But I usually just fast-forward through that anyway! What a great adaptation; I will be watching this for years to come!

I read A Christmas Carol when I was a kid. It was an abridged version, if I recall. So I am familiar with the story, not the book. I was watching the special features on this movie, and they were talking about how this book, even though it was written so long ago, really lends itself well to the animation process, because there are so many things actors can't physically do. And, this is the most faithful adaptation ever. Of course, if you watch the special features on any movie, even one that got horrible reviews, you will hear the actors and backstage people brag about how well they interpreted everything, what a fine cast they had, how perfectly it all came about, etc.

Well, I did enjoy the movie. I enjoyed the animation. I can't really say how faithful it was to the book because I read it too long ago. But the basic story seemed to be there. Scrooge's change from penny-pinching to generous seemed a little abrupt to me. It seemed more from fear than learning. I can agree that they did things that were physically impossible and needed animation for. But then I wonder... why did they use motion capture? They had to set up all those weird contraptions to move around the actors, and then animate most of it anyway. Doesn't that just make it all a lot harder? Like doing it twice? They said (bragged) in the special features that using all the dots on the actors' faces allowed them to capture all the nuances of the actors' expressions. But then, animators on regular computer-animated movies are pretty proud of the expressions they come up with for their characters, too. I don't really get it. Their characters didn't look any more expressive then characters in movies like Shrek. I think they just made more work for themselves. But what the heck. The actors said it was a lot of fun.

Well anyway, I enjoyed WATCHING the movie. I didn't get to see the 3-D version. I'm not a Christmas Carol aficionado with tons of things to compare it to. And I didn't have any little kids to scare. So it was a fun diversion.

When I first heard that Jim Carrey did The Christmas Carol, I chose to avoid it for a very long time.  I remembered seeing his version of The Grinch and was so turned off by it, I kind of swore off Jim Carrey movies for a while.  This Christmas season though, I thought I'd give it a chance.  So, I rented it and was amazed.  The graphics were exceptional.  Everything was immensely beautiful.  Even more than that though, the thing I was the most pleased with was how they chose to stay faithful to the original story by Dickens.  They chose to respect his work, so I am so much the more inclined to respect them for it.  Good job all around.

The only reason I am giving this four stars instead of five was for the few times they chose to abandon Dickens' story line.  There was one scene in particular where Scrooge asks the ghost of Christmas present why he chose to have all of the stores in town close down one day a week.  I assume he is referring to the Sabbath.  The ghost of Christmas present then rebukes organized religion by telling Scrooge to not blame him for the mistakes made by "so called men of the cloth who claim to know me."  Sorry, but I really don't like seeing religion get trashed.

Aside from that though. it was wonderful.  I plan to buy it.

I ordered this dvd and had it shipped to my mom.  While it arrived very quickly, the first problem was,for some reason, she received 2 copies of the same movie.  So, being an honest person, she called Amazon and told them, and they sent her a return mail sticker. She packed up and returned the extra dvd right away.

The second problem came when she went to watch the movie. It kept freezing and wouldn't run longer than the first 3 minutes or so.  This time I contacted Amazon, and then I had to contact Hastings, which is the 2nd party seller.  They said they "were sorry for the problem, but we can't reship, but if I sent it back, they would refund my money."  OK... so I had to print the email w/ the return item sticker, send it to my mom and she once again, had to pack it up and return it.  So, long story short, after about a month, she returned 2 dvds and still didn't get to watch the movie.  They did credit my account, just like they said.

This was a new, in the package movie sold by Amazon, sent by Hastings.

This caricature of Charles Dickens' wonderful Christmas story was not only a complete disappointment, it was a pointless attempt at humor.  Beginning with completely skipping over Ebenezer Scrooge's walk home from his office on Christmas Eve when the first hint of something unusual happening (the ghost horses and hearse)became evident, to the Ghost of Christmas Past portrayed as a disembodied head with its skull on fire, hovering over the ghostly shoulders of a weird little body, and on to an almost total bastardization of a Christmas classic, the kindest thing I can think of to say about this film is, "Shame on Disney."

I was aware before I bought this DVD, of course, that the characters were not real people, but rather computer graphics, but that seemed like it might be kind of a fun film.  I have the movie "The Polar Express," and there are no "real people" in that either, and most of the Polar Express voices belong to Tom Hanks, and that's a most enjoyable film.  But as it turns out here, Jim Carrey as the voice of Scrooge, minus that fantastic talent for visual comedy, was a real loss of what I thought was good potential for an enjoyable version of A Christmas Carol.

I agree with the statement of a couple other reviewers that there are a few questionable scenes in what would most likely be considered a children's movie since it was made by Disney, scenes that might be frightening to young children.  Having viewed this movie, if I had young children, I'd be very reluctant to allow them to watch this one.

For a delightful presentation of a different spin on the Christmas Carol movie, the musical version "Scrooge" is the best so far.

Based upon past reviews I was expecting a wonderful story and excellent 3-D effects.  This movie fails in both departments.  What I was most stunned with, in a negative way, was the corruption of Dickens' story.  How dare screenwriter and director Robert Zemeckis give but a passing glance to Tiny Tim's predicament, Scrooge's lost love, and the joy Scrooge used to have in his heart as a young man.  If the viewer had never seen any past presentations of this story I doubt they could have easily followed, what should have been, clear, emotion filled moral points. Instead, the lack of emotion generating scenes made this a cold, get it done and over with feeling the director must have had in his heart about this entire project.  The difference in volume between the soft spoken scenes and the loud special audio effects was too vast.  It was as though the dialog wasn't considered as important as the crashing and banging.  Also, the needlessly overt visual darkness of most of the movie seemed to be a cheap after thought that was used to try to add an ominous feeling since the directing and script and acting didn't do it.  Speaking of visuals, the 3-D rendering was a complete disappointment.  At best there were a few 5% out of screen moments.  Compared to other 3-D movies this was woefully lacking.  Add to that many out of focus shots and the 3-D version fell flat on it's face.  By no means ever use this movie to showcase your 3-D system to your friends.  They would leave smiling inside at their wise purchase of just a normal television.
I had really been looking forward to this movie.  I ended up shaking my head in disappointment concerning everything about it.  Shame on Disney for releasing this as some sort of accomplishment.

After reading other reviews, I was reluctant to purchase this DVD, but my husband really wanted it so I did.  I certainly understand the sensitivity to scary scenes for small children - but the same would be true for the original and most other versions of "Christmas Carol".  It is a somewhat dark story - with a redemptive ending.  The dialogue is very close to the book, often quoting and even showing the illustrations.  The special effects are extremely well done and I found little to criticize.

impressive special effects but i find the characters' look creepy---their eyes are weird and glass like--it has many nice things about it but i couldn't get over the look of the people. And why is Cratchit so short? some of the girls tower over him. My favorite is still George C Scott with the fabulous Edward Woodward.

With income-disparity at a level not seen since the turn of the last century, Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol" has never seemed more timely and relevant in its spirit and message.  No longer just a quaint little tale from a distant past, the story, with its themes of unbridled greed and compassion for the poor, speaks with a renewed urgency to our current generation.

So, polemics aside, how does the 2009 "motion-capture" animated version of this most famous of all stories stack up against the umpteen others we've seen over the course of a lifetime (including those featuring The Muppets and Mr Magoo)?  Very well, actually.  Robert Zemechis' movie remains generally faithful to the source material, and, while it provides us with a visually ravishing - almost snow globe-like - look at a wintry 19th Century London, it isn't afraid to confront the darker elements of the tale as well (as such, it might be a bit frightening for very young kids at times).  And while one could accuse it of going a trifle overboard in its search for the requisite 3-D sensation (as most of these films by their very nature are won't to do), the movie remains forever focused on the human heart that beats at the core of the work.

Even in semi-animated form, Jim Carrey is so remarkable as the miser Scrooge (and the three main ghosts who visit him) that, in the spirit of the holidays, we're even willing to forgive him for his desecration of the Grinch a decade or so back.  And he's backed by a first-class cast that includes Robin Wright Penn, Gary Oldman, Colin Firth, Bob Hoskins, and Cary Elwes among others.

All minor quibbles and qualms aside, you'd have to be a bah-humbugging Scrooge yourself to resist the charms of this movie.

The sound on this video is turned down so low that we had to turn the volume of our TV up full blast, and then move our chairs closer. The movie itself is good, but the sound quality of the actual video was very poor. I think Disney might've done this on purpose to keep people from showing it to large groups.

Poor Charles must be spinning in his grave. With all due respect to the other reviewers who thought this was faithful to the original story, what Christmas Carol did you read?! I don't recall Ebenezer surfing a rooftop on an icicle or rocketing into the stratosphere after snuffing out Christmas past in the Dickens classic.

This is a prime example of a movie made solely to showcase 3D. Zemeckis has proven with Polar Express that he can make a great movie where the special effects are embellishments to a good story line. Not here. Lest you forget, nearly every scene is designed around showing off just how cool 3D can be, whether it's Marley spitting or an insect sized Scrooge rocketing down a drain pipe (I'm sorry, what page is that on in the book?)

If you want a 3D thrill-ride, where Tiny Tim takes a backseat to the special effects, you'll love this. If you want a heart warming version of a classic tale - Alistair Sims version remains the gold standard.

I know that my title is suggesting a lot, but let me explain. I've had this battle about which Christmas Carol is the best adaptation of the book with many friends and most of the time, I get that the George C Scott version, A Christmas Carol is the best. So I watched it and to be honest, it was a great version, but I think it had many faults. However I won't get into that here since this review is for the Disney version. Let's get to it. THE STORY I saw a review here stating that this movie moved too slow through the emotional scenes and too quickly through everything else. Your opinion on this may differ depending on how you interpret the book, but for me, this story is a heartfelt tale of a grumpy old man who hates happiness mainly because he doesn't have any. You're supposed to hate this man while trying to figure out why everyone around him has sympathy. Only later on when Scrooge is visited by his spirits do you begin to understand how he got to be the way he is. And right about the moment you start feeling your own sympathies, you watch Scrooge begin to "open his eyes". After the spirits have shown him his past, present and future, Scrooge has an awakening and realizes what's really important in life. The reason I mentioned all that is because although this book was written during part of Charles Dickens' darkside of storytelling and "A Christmas Carol" was (or is) supposed to be a ghost story, I feel like with today's audience, this story won't scare anyone, so it's nice to have a bit of the warm side. Other adaptations of this story do not have much of a warm side, but the Disney version seems to capture both. The speed of this film is perfect. If you watch the other versions with the book in hand, it almost feels like the actors are simply reading their lines and jumping from one scene to the next with no time for the audience to take in what is transpiring. That's why I do not think this version moves too slow. Unlike the George C. Scott version, I find that with Disney's version, Scrooge makes a more believable transformation in the end. Because he starts out as a feeble old man, it becomes very believable that he's only being mean because he has an unhappy side to him. This is why the people around him feel so much sympathy. It's almost like it's not his fault. To me, this makes the best Scrooge. The problem with George C. Scott is that he's already a very powerful and dominating force (and great actor), so he's already expected to be a mean person. This makes it feel like at the end of that movie, Scrooge is more or less just being nice because he has to and not because he really had a life-changing night. There's not much of a distinction between angry George C. Scott and happy George C. Scott! Disney's version makes Scrooge very humble in the end...almost to the point of groveling (although he doesn't). The reason this sold it for me was because it made me feel like the spirits really shook him to his core. He was genuinely scared and sad throughout the whole process, thus the end reactions appear more genuine. The end scene at his nephew's house even has a bit of sadness to it. It's hard to get choked up over animated movies, but this one comes very close! I think that if this movie had been live-action, Jim Carrey might not have sold me on Scrooge only because it's hard to see Jim Carrey as a mean person. However, the way he voiced Scrooge really brings it home. THE SPIRITS A lot of reviews hated the spirits in this version for either being too weird, too obnoxious or too scary. I find all three of these assessments to be false. In almost every adaptation, the Spirit of Christmas Present is generally the same, but the other two vary dramatically. I found that what Disney did with the Spirit of Christmas Past (making him a candle) fit in best with how Dickens described him in the book. It made it much easier to visualize a spirit with a head glowing of bright light (the flame) and it made more sense as to why he was holding a snuffer. Granted, the comparison might be unfair to past iterations because this movie employs special effects that we didn't have in the past, but still...I think it's much better. The one thing I liked a lot was that the first two spirits were acted out by Jim Carrey too. When reading the book, you almost want to believe that the spirits are actually figments of Scrooge's own imagination, therefore they would probably be in his own image. In this movie, they are just that and they make no attempt at hiding this fact. That in itself offered a little more to the "coolness" factor. The Spirit of Christmas Future is what really makes this movie seem scary, but that's where we get into the realm of the original story being a ghost story. I really like that Disney didn't "Disney-fy" it too much. Of course, there is some concern with this film being too scary for young children as it deals with death and is generally a very dark picture, but keeping it inline with the story was very important and this version does just that. If you're concerned about your children, just watch it with them and explain to them what's going on. They'll understand. THE SOUND One of the areas where this movie excels is the sound and music. If you have the option, watch this on your home theatre system and you'll be mesmerized by how the littlest of sound will be so prevalent in very quiet scenes. I find that this adds to the drama and even creates a bit of fear in some parts. Even the voices are crisp and clear. The sound of falling snow sounds just as it would. It almost let's you hear what cold sounds like...if that's possible! The soundtrack is just as fabulous although this film is not heavily scored. I find that it uses music in just the right places and by doing so, it doesn't drown out what's happening. CONCLUSION I find something I like in all versions of A Christmas Carol and I've seen a lot! However, I really loved the book and it always makes me wonder off to some cold city in England of the past where Christmas is a vibrant time during the coldest part of the year. I wonder how life would have been back in those times and I try to imagine what it would be like to live in a place like that. Unfortunately, many of the film adaptations still feel like we're on a movie set and things don't always look right. This version, however really illustrates an almost perfect collection of scenes that seem to flow seamlessly from one to the next. Of course, the fact that this movie is animated helps out a lot since they can do whatever they want with a virtual world, but that's ok! If that's the best way to tell a story like this, then so be it. None of what I said above is meant to disregard any other version of this story as they are all great in their own way. But in the end, this has become my favorite.
The 3D video was fantastic! The quality was absolutely excellent! Service from Amazon was the usual fine effort on their part. I'm very pleased and would recommend the 3Dversion to anyone.

First off I must say that I am generally NOT a Jim Carrey fan.  I find his humor to be crass and most of his movies are not funny to me except for a few.  However, I find this to be an excellent movie and Jim Carrey's flexibility in acting are great in this movie.  He plays a wide variety of characters, from Ebenezer Scrooge to the Ghost of Christmas Past, and the Ghost of Christmas Present, and a few more.  I was impressed with his voice overs.  The animation is outstanding and I enjoy the "special effects" which compliment this classic story by Charles Dickens.  I remember when it first came out in theatres.  I decided not to see it because as I have stated, I am generally not a Jim Carrey fan.  I saw it on DVD last Christmas season and was quite pleasantly suprized.
For those of you who are not a Jim Carrey fan, I must say that you should see this movie if you chose not to watch any of his other movies.  This one is NOT a disappointment or insulting in anyway.  I really enjoyed it and will watch it during the Christmas season for years to come.  Highly Recommended!

When I watched this on a video streaming site, I was not sure what to expect.  Wow!  Was I pleasantly surprised!  The animation is spectacular!  The skin textures of the close-up shots!  The eyes capture the emotions of the characters - particularly in one scene when Cratchit and Scrooge are face-to-face on the stairway of Cratchit's home.  I loved the portrayal of the Grim Reaper as only a morphing shadow.  Wonderful creativity while staying true to the Dickens tale.  Carry does an excellent job not over-acting this part.  The only drawback I can see to this film is some minor cartoon-ish moments that remind you that you really *are* watching an animated film.  I will definitely get this on blue-ray to see all the detail that I missed on my first viewing.

Watched this with the family tonight and it was nearly a complete flop. We rarely watch PG with our little ones but they had seen older versions of A Christmas Carol and were familiar with the story - this one is pumped full of adrenaline and creepiness. Really? Why? The tale is much better told for meaning than for thrills. I guess maybe those bases were covered with the earlier, and in my opinion much better, versions of the tale adapted to film.

That said the voice acting was good and I am fond of the actors involved (in general). The CGI was ... well creepy but good (in a Polar Express way). The story stayed pretty much true to Dickens' work - but it diluted it with 3D moments and action. Perhaps this speaks to the tween/teen market better than traditional dramatizations but it just wasn't really for us.

With at least four very good live action versions in circulation we won't need to view this 'amped up' version again.

Just our .02

This film has been completely rendered in CGI.  As such it has some advantages over, and yet alternatively suffers when compared to, the best live action dramas.  In addition, this production cannot seem to decide whether it is to be a dark yet faithful adaptation of Dickens' work, or a pratfall-strewn, cartoon comedy.  With feet in both camps, it ends up unsuccessful in each.  There can be no question that CGI can offer a lot to enhance such a costume drama.  Every inanimate object was rendered faithfully and sometimes astonishingly.  The city of London in the 19th century was wonderfully presented.  The filming of Spirits and other spectral events can be greatly enhanced by CGI effects.  But ultimately it is the characters that sell the story.  The animated people in this production looked waxy and unrealistic.  Facial expressions lacked the sublime subtlety of reality.  Eyes were glassy and expressionless resembling audio-animatronic figures more than real human beings.  Things were not helped by the screenwriters' inability to come to grips with how they wanted to tell the story.  The pratfalls and comic chases clashed alarmingly with the dark and creepy aspects of the rest of the story.  Much of the film was a straight telling of Dickens' tale and was obviously well-researched as many details provided in the novella were accurately rendered.  Yet in its schizophrenia, the film also chooses at times to dispense with any effort at accuracy or even verisimilitude by inserting ridiculous scenes of cartoon-like quality.  If one wants a satisfying cartoon version of the Dickens tale, both amusing and touching, one need only view Disney's "Mickey's Christmas Carol".  In short, while at times quite accurate, its deficiencies make it difficult to recommend this film as the most accurate filmic representation of Dickens.  You can read in more detail a comparison of this and other film treatments of Dickens' classic at dickenscroogemovies dot com.

There are many versions of A Christmas Carol, and this is one of the best.  A Christmas Carol is one of my all-time favorite movies so I have seen every version.  Everyone should own Disney's A Christmas Carol!!

First, just because the Disney name is attached, do not think for a moment that this is a movie suitable for young children.  It is not.  Who it is suitable for is fully grown adults.  The visual effects are absolutely stunning, and the story is very faithful to the actual Dickens book.  Frankly, it can be quite disturbing to young viewers.  But it can also be disturbing to adult viewers in a way that Dickens himself would most likely have approved.  In fact, I think it relays the message he intended to relay: Fear death now while ye yet live and can make changes.

I knew from the moment that Jacob Marley made his deathly appearance, wrapped in chains that he forged in life, that this was going to be a moving experience.

Scrooge: "What do you want with me?"

Marley (dragging his chains): "Ooooh, much! ... Aaaaaahg!"

Throughout his conversation with Scrooge, he is preoccupied with looking at the chains he is bound with.  "I wear the chains I forged in life.  I made it link by link and yard by yard.  Can you recognize it's pattern?  Can you imagine the lengths and weight of the chain you bear?  Yours is a ponderous chain".

The ghost of Christmas past is ghostly, and his voice is like the flickering of the candle he is represented as.  The Ghost of Christmas Present dies as though by heart attack while a giant bell tolls.  And the Ghost of Christmas yet to Come is, frankly, frightening - even to an adult.  He appears as nothing more than something like a three dimensional shadow.  The kind of thing that makes me wish I had seen this one, at least, in 3D on the big screen.

The story is fantastically faithful to the original text as penned by Dickens.  The dialogue is fantastic, even by today's standards: "Would you so soon put out, with your worldly hands, the light that I give?"

Just.... WOW.

There are certain things about this animated  Disney version of "The Christmas Carol" that are unique and amazing.  However, there are other things that are mundane and quite lacking in creativity.  When Charles Dickens wrote this beloved tale it was told in a simple manner with a good life's lesson to be learned.  However, the lack of concentration on the Bob Crachit family was appalling.  One of the most important aspects of the Dicken's tale (besides the revival of a GOOD Ebenezer Scrooge) was the strength of this little family as they stood up to poverty with grace and dignity. Yes, there are scenes with the little family gathering about the  Christmas table, but they were  too short.  You never really get to know or understand who and what they were.  Once Ebenezer has a change of heart you don't experience the joy that such a dramatic change should bring.  It simply fell flat. Scenes with  the Ghost of Christmas Past were bright and creative and beautifully done.  Seeing young Ebenezer before he became the miser frankly fell flat.  However, it was delightful seeing his old employer and his wife as they exploded with Christmas cheer.  I felt as if the makers of this film rushed the story and the viewer was left wanting the missing pieces of a puzzle. The film is colorful and the art work is very good, but  I felt that it was only half a story being told, and wondered where the rest of the tale might be.  One does not experience the sudden wonder when the change takes place in Scrooge and you miss that.  I "liked" the film, but I did not love it.
Love this movie....it is computer generated and the characters look real. If you like the Polar Express you will also enjoy this movie.

Jim Carrey stars as Scrooge and also plays the roles of the spirits - past, present and future.  Rather than his usual, silly style of acting, and what I refer to as "overacting," he does a serious, Oscar-worthy job here. The film was created using stop-motion animation, similar to "The Polar Express."  It is like combining reality with fantasy resulting in mesmerizing characters. It must have taken a really long time to make this movie. I cannot even imagine what that process is like!

What I love about this version of A Christmas Carol is that it is quite true to Charles Dickens' original story.  Carrey portrays the misery and unparalleled nastiness of Ebeneezer Scrooge perfectly. That combined with the magic of 3D makes for a most extraordinary movie-going experience. For a Miami girl like me, it was a true pleasure being snowed upon! This animation makes you feel as if you are Scrooge himself, flying with the ghosts, running from fear and being overcome with regret. There are many creepy scenes, and for that reason I say this movie may be too scary for very young children.

The only thing I was not crazy about was a scene where Scrooge is frantically running through the streets, being chased by a dark carriage. The story line here seems to go on and on, and just when you feel relieved that it is over, the creepy carriage reappears a few more times. It did not make a lot of sense to me.

After watching this movie, I asked myself, "What is it about these classic, overly familiar stories that keep us coming back for more?" I think the answer is that we love what we know, yet we want to experience familiarity in original ways. Does that make any sense to you? The fact that Scrooge, a totally unlikeable, unfeeling human can face his own cruelty, be filled with regret and then change, gives us all hope for ourselves and others.

What if you came face-to face with the spirits of your past, present and future? What would you see? What would you want to change?

Everyone and his mother knows the story of this one and there needs no rehashing, so the question then becomes one of execution. Were there spins to this tale that brought us to a better understanding of it while still remaining faithful to the story? For me, the answer was no. This fully CGI tale, like the aliens in Avatar (Original Theatrical Edition) and Gollum in The Lord of the Rings: The Motion Picture Trilogy (Special Extended Edition), featured characters based off actors being scanned by computers and then filling in the images later. While this was a different interpretation of the story, I felt that Zemeckis fell a little too in love with the technology and lost focus on what matters--the story. With a lot of swooping camera shots and a head-scratching action sequence involving a miniaturized Scrooge, this was turned into empty spectacle, not to mention I found it a little creepy seeing Gary Oldman's face on Bob Cratchit's body. As for the story itself, I found Scrooge's transformation forced, a product more because the makers wanting it to happen rather than arising naturally from the character. While this version may appeal to children or anyone who hasn't seen one of the umpteen other versions of this story, it probably won't work for those us who have seen it before. For me, the best version is the one with George C. Scott in the role of Scrooge A Christmas Carol [Blu-ray].

Another Christmas, and Hollywood has another remake of the Dickens' classic ready to go.  This time we have Jim Carrey playing Scrooge.  Though this might seem crazy at first, as Carrey is a comedian and this story is a drama, remember that Carrey carried the the live-action adaptation of the Grinch Who Stole Christmas.  And he does it again with this movie, which I think is the best adaptation of A Christmas Carol.  All the previous CGI-flicks directed by Robert Zemeckis has finally led to this impressive work.  The music is good, the animation is spot-on, the dialog is perfect, and the action is engaging.  The special effects are probably the movie's  highlight, but they serve the movie, allowing the film's story to be told in new ways, and do not distract from either the plot or the dialog.  And like Tom Hanks in Polar Express, Jim Carrey plays multiple characters in this movie, including the ghosts of Christmas past, present and future.  It is his acting in these scenes that show him at his best.  The movie's representation of the ghost of Christmas present was the best one I've ever seen, with an innovative way of having the ghost take Scrooge around London to show how his peers are talking about him.  Overall, probably the best Christmas movie of the year.

I have many versions of scrooge and of Christmas Carol, and they are all wonderful, including this one.  It's one of those movies that can cause you to think about how YOU are living, provided you give yourself permission to look within yourself, and make some vital changes in areas which you may not be living right in God's eyes as He sees what you're doing daily, weekly and so on. Very inspirational and ministering to the heart, mind and soul. I believe that is what Scrooge and Christmas Carol were created for to begin with.

Just my opinion of course.

Amazon gave us an exchange, but lesson learned, rush to watch bluray movies you buy, as they don't seem to have good quality control. The exchange wounded up coming with a damaged case and the same crinkled ring on the 2d disc. I ended up putting together the best of the 2 copies and sent back the dilapidated mess. I should knock it more stars for the quality of the disc, but I feel it's isolated. The movie is good, a much more truthful version of the classic book. I loved it esp. all the old creaky english accents and grey palor over the whole scenery. Not quite the movie for children but scrooge's revelation is that much more joyful with the abject misery portrayed in the beginning.

Charles Dickens' A Christmas Carol is one of my all-time favorite books, and this is one of my all-time favorite movies. It is not only an incredibly faithful adaptation (all of Dickens' best dialogue and descriptions make it in), but it stands alone as its own piece of art--frightening, beautiful, funny, and perfectly heartwarming. I don't see young children loving this film, but I absolutely adore it.

Charles Dickens' beloved story "Christmas Carol" has been filmed at least five times.  I really like the motion capture Disney's CHRISTMAS CAROL directed by Robert Zemeckis.  Jim Carrey plays at least five roles.  Terrific production design  infuses every scene and the movie sticks to the story that Dickens wrote.  Originally intended for Imax 3D, the Blu-ray 2D looks great on a hi-def flat-screen TV.

I'm not going to get caught up in the debate on whether or not this is a good version of the Dickens classic.  I think the movie is fine and it is impossible to please everyone. Others may have a particular version that they like better.  I've liked the story since I was a child.  What I REALLY like about this version is the 3D which I think is excellent!  The characters are so life like and it is truly a joy to watch this version.  Zemeckis does not dissappoint! I'm sure I'll probably watch this Blu Ray every year during the holidays if not more often.

***  Would have rated it excellent if more effects were farther out but OVER ALL VERY NICE 3D  ***

MY 3D RATING = VERY GOOD  (poor, fair, good, very good, excellent)

Note: As far as the percentages go, everyone's eyes are different. What I see at 25% you may see at 15% or 35%. To fully realize how far something is out of the screen for you, pause on an effect and direct a partner with an extended finger to the tip of what you are seeing. You may be surprised.

There's so many movies about scrooge that were made...and its basically the same

I thought this was a great movie it got a little off track with the ghost of christmas to come but followed the original movie pretty much until that part. Too many old classics get really screwed up with remakes but this was decent and all family members can watch this. Great family movie for every xmas.

This movie is very dark and since we watched both this version of A Christmas Carole and the musical version with Kelsey Grammer, there is no comparison. This version is not fun. Our young son didn't care for it, although my husband liked it far more than I did.

Was concerned that Disney would veer from the Dickens original story line and presence of Jim Carrey would "ham it up" but was pleasantly surprised how well this version stayed true to original. 3D wasn't used as a gimmick either, it did add to the viewing experience. Worth viewing!!

We really enjoyed this offering. Carrey did a great job on the voices, as did the other wonderful cast! We did think the Ghost of Christmas Present's wasting away was a bit too frightening for younger children though! Other than that, a great retelling of a Holiday favorite!!
I am a great fan of the movie A Christmas Carol and this was a particularly great version.  I absolutely loved it and will be watching it every CHristmas!!!

The 3d was pretty good. The story is what it always is with this movie. Nothing too great. I would get a used copy if you could as I don't think the money is worth it on a new copy. You'll watch the movie once or twice a year during the holidays until they make a new format.

Wasn't sure what to expect when my son asked me to by this to watch on the 3D TV I bought him for Christmas.  I was very pleasantly surprised. I was expecting typical Disney and Jim Carey high comedy instead this version was more frightening ala the book.  The 3D effects really enhanced the storyline.

I liked it.  I own many many versions of the story, and each brings an interesting interpretation of the various characters, most notably, Scrooge.
