I was really excited to buy this movie on DVD and watch it with my family this year.  My husband and I have a 2 year old toddler and thought that watching the Christmas Carol movie with him would be such a treat each holiday season. Plus, it is made by Disney, so I thought for sure it will be kid friendly and well made...  Well, my husband and I were both deeply disappointed in this version.  I think it is one of the worst ones out there... I love the actors and couldn't believe how bad this movie was.  It was a horror flick for my little one, - Scrooge looks super creepy and the ghost of Marley is un-necessarily horifying with his mouth snapping out of joint and all... This is NOT a movie to watch with little children!  Actually, my husband didn't want to watch it much past the ghost of Christmas Past.  Many of the important parts of the story were completely left out... for example, the scene where Scrooge's father mistreats him during his youth is not in this movie at all. I also have to say that the ghost of Christmas Past is just a freaky made-up character that looks like a jittery candle with a face... not at all creative in my opinion!  Well, enough said, I returned this one!

Just another movie is all, nothing that noteworthy here. The characters seemed a bit lifeless, the pacing was too slow, and the sound equalizing was terrible (I had to constantly turn up the volume to even hear what was being said, but then turn it way down again as the sound effects and music got way too loud).

In the hands of Robert Zemeckis and Jim Carrey, Ebenezer Scrooge's tale delivers moments of true emotion - frightening, heartbreaking and uplifting. Yet, neither the 3-D animation nor Carrey's multi-character act elevate this version to the status of a Christmas classic. I preface I'm writing this review as a father of two sons (ages 8 and 6). We popped popcorn, poured glasses of Arnold Palmer and slipped into our pajamas for a family movie night. Having recently enjoyed The Muppet Christmas Carol, I hoped my sons could enjoy (and follow) a gloomier interpretation of Dickens' classic that followed the original story closer than I had expected. Zemeckis employs the performance-capture technique previously used in The Polar Express and Beowulf. The animation provides some amazing visuals, making it possible for Scrooge to fly Victorian England or shrink to mouse size for an icicle ride across rooftops. The ghost of Marley and the Ghost of Christmas Future were exceptionally scary (my six-year jumped when Marley's visage first appeared on Scrooge's doorknocker). However, the animation distracts as much as it dazzles, especially during longer stretches of dialogue. Aside from the skeletal Scrooge, Zemeckis envisions the rest of the cast as a fleshy, pig-faced people whose ugliness is off-putting. Scrooge is an amalgamation of Carrey's previous roles. You'll see a sneer that echoes Count Olaf from Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events and then hear a laugh reminiscent of The Grinch from How the Grinch Stole Christmas. Carrey's performances as the Ghosts of Christmases Past, Present and Future are for vanity's sake. My six-year old detected the same actor played Scrooge and the Ghosts, a revelation that only served to pull him from the narrative. Robin Wright Penn, Gary Oldman, Cary Elwes and Bob Hoskins join Carrey in playing multiple roles. It is hard to understand why though because only Oldman, who portrays both Jacob Marley and Bob Cratchit, delivers two unique and satisfying performances. Marley is gruesome (much more horrifying than the Ghost of Christmas Future), while Cratchit is endearing and childlike, especially so during his commute home on Christmas Eve. In summary, this movie is a mess and falls well short of being a Christmas classic. Dickens classic proves beyond the creative talents of Carrey and Zemeckis, who are unsure how to present this tale. Dark and gloomy dialogue is followed by Tom and Jerry action scenes. Rating: Two stars. If you have young children, I recommend The Muppet Christmas Carol instead.

Okay, so motion capture animation has gotten a little better, but more on that later!

I've reviewed a few versions of "A Christmas Carol" here on Amazon and finally got around to watching this one. Everybody knows the story about Scrooge by now, and I'm too lazy to go over the synopsis, but I will say much of this adaption is beautifully made and it's fairly faithful to Dickens...fairly.

I suppose we've come to expect cinematic adaptations to be a bit over the top. So when Disney and Jim Carrey decided to come out with their own interpretation of Ebenezer Scrooge, we had to know there would be physical comedy, chase scenes and overt sentimentality. It certainly wouldn't have the subtlety of Masterpiece Theater (although wouldn't you love to see their take on the story starring someone like, say, Ian McKellen as Scrooge?) Anyway, over the top is certainly what we got. And I don't mind seeing Scrooge flying over London from the second story of his house, or being chased through the streets by a ghostly horse-drawn carriage, or even needlessly shrinking down to the size of a mouse. The problem is there's SO MUCH of this kind of junk involved, it truncates the spirit of the story. If you were to strip away all the goofy additional material, you would realize you're watching nothing but cliffnotes in motion capture. For example, it just seemed odd that Scrooge would get emotional about Tiny Tim's plight considering he barely had time to connect with the lad.

As far as the horse-drawn carriage chase and the Scrooge-shrinkage, the problem is they go on WAY too long! And it seems to me, the purpose of Scrooge witnessing some of these events in the future are defeated while he's preoccupied fleeing from the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come through London streets or avoiding blows from a poker wielded by Old Joe! You'll see what I mean, when you watch the movie.

Jim Carrey actually does a pretty good job as Scrooge. I just don't understand why him. It seems like any number of fine British actors could have voiced the role, or motion captured the role, or whatever the heck you want to call it. He's not particularly impressive as the Ghost of Christmas Present, however, who's maniacal laughing only annoys after a while. Speaking of the Ghost of Christmas Present, what a horrible way to depict his demise. Nothing expresses "Merry Christmas" like watching a jolly bearded ghost waste away to bone and ash! Speaking of macabre imagery, I know they meant to be funny when Jacob Marley's jaw cracks open, but double-u-tee-eff? I'm starting to think they missed the boat not having Scrooge resemble Vincent Price! It all would have made sense then! Oh, and I have no idea what was going on with Marley's eyes.

All the other voices were fine, except Colin Firth. An actor I normally love, he seemed to over exaggerate his vocal performance...like he was all too aware he was in an animated feature.

Now about this whole motion capture business. I know they've made some advances in the technology. And it's true the job done on Scrooge himself is the best we've seen so far. But as impressive has his character looks, everyone else still looked (as Dickens described Jacob Marley) dead as a doornail! They just haven't mastered the eyes of the characters and can't shake the creep factor. Perhaps there's something to be said for traditional animation that Robert Zemeckis hasn't figured out. Animated characters should LOOK like animated characters...exaggerated features and all. The more animation strives for reality, the more perfect they need to be in capturing the details, especially the eyes, which are called the "windows of the soul" for a reason.

These Zemeckis characters are still soulless creatures unable to depict the subtle emotions of Bugs Bunny, let alone a flesh and blood actor!

I wouldn't say this is the worst adaptation of "A Christmas Carol" I've ever seen as it is handsomely made and highly energetic. Plus, I was intrigued by the Ghost of Christmas Present's lecture regarding "men of the cloth". Still, it's pretty close to being the worst!
A good Christmas movie. Is approprite for any age range, but it could be a little scary for the little ones. It is a good remake of the classic Charles Dicken's Movie. Loved It

First of all my wife and I go nearly every year to see our local Guthrie theater's production of 'A Christmas Carol' so we've seen many interpertations of Charles Dicken's story.  I'm not going to go into great detail reviewing the film, but Disney sticks to the classic retelling and make no mistake, Jim Carrey is an excellent Scrooge, I loved his accent and he wasn't the wacky Pet Detective...  It's a top notch movie production from start to end.  If I had to nit-pick I'd say the chase scene during the ghost of Christmas future was a bit overdone, but it's a minor nusance as this is one of the best movie-versions of Dicken's story and in glorious 3D, the closest you'll get to going to an actual theatrical production with live actors.

The 1080p 3D was simply outstanding on our Samsung Plasma display.  Incredible depth and detail.  Blows the doors off of the newest 3D version of Polar Express.

Disney is way ahead of the curve here and I seek their products out whenever possible.  Here they have included FIVE versions of the film.  3D-BRD, 2D-BRD, DVD, Digital Copy, AND..streaming!  By putting the Disney Rewards Code into your Disney website membership, you unlock streaming of the film from the Disney website.  I tested this at home and at my office it works great with excellent quality.

You most certainly will not be disappointed in Jim Carrey's performance at all. I was expecting an over the top performance, aka "How the Grinch Stole Christmas".  Truthfully, if you did not know he was the lead in this movie, you would not even recognize that he is the iconic fabled Ebineezer Scrooge. I honestly believe that this version of "A Christmas Carol" will soon become a Christmas classic. The 3d format takes this movie to a far superior home viewing experience.

In my opinion, this is one of the better versions of "A Christmas Carol" ever made. Normally, I'm not a fan of Jim Carey's, but as this illustrated character, he's not so bad. The animation is wonderful! It will be viewed as a tradition in my home now.

I've always loved the Christmas Carol story and have collected many of the different versions, but this version is by far, the best ever. The visuals are stunning and Jim Carrey's character portrayals are brilliant! I highly recommend that everyone buy this and make watching it with your family a Christmas tradition!

I had a hard time sitting through this entire film.  Maybe it is because I can almost recite the whole Christmas Carol movie by heart from all the different versions I have seen.  But, this has to be one of the worst versions I have ever seen.  I was so disappointed in it.  I thought it would be funny, but I just found it stupid.

The animation is great no doubt about that. The story is faithful to the novel no complaint there. Boy it was much more scary. The scene with Jacob Marley's ghost is so graphic with his mouth cracking open and this horrid black tongue hanging out. I am an adult and it was to scary and it was gross. I had to look away. To top it off I did fall asleep that never happens in the Polar Express. So I have mixed emotions. Also when you get a DVD they usually have the picture of the cover on the DVD, no so this is the plain gray you get when you rent from a place like Netfix. Made it feel like I was getting a discount cut down copy. Not that it totally matters but with all things considered it was one more disappointment. The best part is the bonus material on how it was made and the reactions of the actors. I wanted this to be a 5 star but it just is not and I sure wouldn't show it to children under 10 years old. This is the stuff of nightmares. I'll stick with the original B & W versionA Christmas Carol (Ultimate Collector's Edition)(B/W & Color) and the Muppets Christmas Carol which I love.The Muppet Christmas Carol - Kermit's 50th Anniversary Edition

Story:
This is VERY different in many respects from the Dickens story. There are some glaring changes that really take away from the beauty of this classic story.

Changes for 3D effect:
1. The "flying" effect with the Ghost of Christmas Present was not, was not even implied, in the Dickens story.
2. Scrooge being chased around the streets of London after meeting the Ghost of Christmas Future.
3. Scrooge being shrunk to the size of a mouse, running around the London sewers, snowboarding with an icicle, and getting nearly pounded by Joe the rag and bones man.

Changes made for no apparent reason:
1. Many important scenes are left out that show the progression of Scrooge from greedy miser to keep of Christmas all year long.
2. The Ghost of Christmas Present dies, rots to a skeleton, turns to dust, and is blown away by the wind.

One change that really, really got on my nerves was the Ghost of Christmas Present making a dig at "men of the cloth." I don't know if the writer/director/producer was trying to be overtly anti-Christian here, but that's surely the way it comes off. (Which makes you wonder why they'd make a movie about the miracle of Christmas if they want to be anti-Christian.)

The result is a movie that falls well short of the great film it could have been. For one, it scared my daughter (3 years old) quite a bit; the movie is loud and spends a lot of time getting "in your face" for the 3D effects. Also, have I mentioned that the Ghost of Christmas Present, who of course looks a lot like Santa, DIES...and TURNS INTO A SKELETON!

There are some nice extras on the disk. I like watching the technical features about motion-capture, but I had to laugh out loud when the directors, actors, producer, etc. were talking about "how true they stayed to Dickens' story."

The story adaptation gets 0 stars, all the little changes add up to this being not a very good telling of the story. The motion-capture, including how amazingly lifelike the facial features came out, gets 5 stars.

I went back and forth about if I should get this movie. I absolutely love the animation on the Polar Express so I finally decided to get this. I was so excited to see this with my kids. Well let me tell you, this is not for children. My nine year old was even hiding his eyes at times. I gave this movie about 15 minutes before finally turning it off. What a disappointment. I wanted a good family Christmas movie to see with my kids and this was not it. I thought being a Disney movie it would not be so scary. Boy was I wrong!

We rented "Disney's A Christmas Carol" with plans for a family movie night but soon realized it was way too creepy and scary for our kids to watch. They didn't even argue about having to leave the room since they had lost interest in watching it from what they had seen in the very beginning. The ghosts were extra creepy and Scrooge was more unlikeable than ever with no redeeming qualities at all. The voices were so over-done and heavily accented that the dialogue was difficult to understand. Very, very disappointed in this movie. I didn't even care how great the animation looked, I just wanted it to end. I'll have my kids watch the Muppet's Christmas Carol instead.
This is a great movie for the whole family. I love this movie. Amazon.com got the movie to me right on time and in good condition.

A Christmas Carol, remake, that's sure to entertain both adults and children alike:) This movie revisits/revisizes this classic tale, and adds todays technology of computer generated animation to the tale. Jim Carrey depicts the old, miserly, & not so friendly Mr. Ebeeneezer Scrooge. The charming tale of C. Dickens follows the storyline quite well!! Although, I will say, I myself coming from a generation prior to the computer age, that this classic tale is more enjoyable in earlier accounts both on film and in plays, this movie still brings a fun themed genre to the current times:) I highly recommend this to any Christmas/Holiday lover!!! Great Fun!!!

while the animation was superb, I still fell asleep- which rarely ever happens in movies.
i guess part of it was TOO over-the-top... perhaps TOO 3D heavy-handed...
the story isn't new- through, it is signature...
I'm sticking with the Muppets Christmas Carol...

My husband and I rented this movie, looking forward to watching it. We both enjoy most Jim Carrey movies, and like the story of the Christmas Carol. But this movie was so frightening! I jumped five times while watching this movie and did not enjoy it. I would not recommended this movie for young children! Other reviews here mention their children having nightmares and that is not a surprise to me.
We were very disappointed in this version with Jim Carrey.  It was quite boring.  We like the original Christmas Carol and even the Muppet Christmas Carol.  We felt no Christmas Spirit in this movie.

First of all I have to say I really wanted to like this film. I had high expectations for it. It was reasonably faithful to the book, the characters were well done. But there were a few things done in the name of 3D that took away from the story in the movie and made it seem silly in the end. Scrooge taking a fall backwards off his porch
when he sees the "Marley Knocker". The way the Ghost of Christmas Past's Cap goes off like a roman candle sending Scrooge across the sky. The way the Ghost of Christmas Present takes him around on his visit. The way the Ghost of Christmas Present "dies"  In the clock tower.  The events of the visit with the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come. The shrinking of Scrooge, the hearse chase. A huge departure from the book, or a Hollywood attempt to "improve" upon the original story to" punch it up". None of which helped the story at all. Otherwise visually this was a great looking movie, Even the soundtrack is a wonderful one, It just could have been so much more.

A Christmas Carol is a story that needs real set, and people. The story is there, but hard as they tried in they're animation effort the facial emotions are not. I felt disconnected. It is because of this I hated movie. I am glad I rented it. Thank God for Redbox.

Pathetic.  The blatant jab at Christianity in the dialogue between Scrooge and the ghost of Christmas present is nauseating.  Shows how much the creators of this movie know about Christianity or Christmas for that matter. Again, pathetic!

I so enjoyed Jim Carrey in Disney's "Christmas Carol". I had been wanting to see it since it was released and finally bought it through Amazon. The story was very close to the book by Charles Dickens. I was amazed at the amount of big named actors in the movie also. Disney "did it" again.
Very good purchase. the only thinkg that I didn't realize is that the 3D disc is only for a 3D television. So be warned that when a movies is in blu-ray 3D, its only playable on a 3D television set.

Because I'm a techno-geek, I went to the "Behind the Scenes" parts before I ever watched the movie.  While the creators patted themselves on the back about how faithful they were to the spirit (pun intended, I'm sure) of how Dickens probably visualized the movie, I had to see for myself, of course.

Then I watched the movie.  All of my comments are based on what I have always felt about this classic.

The good:
* A very good Scrooge.  Jim Carrey's Scrooge is the Scrooge of my imagination, from my childhood.  This is one time I have to agree with the creators of the film.  This was the perfect Scrooge.
* A very good Tiny Tim.  Ditto for everything I said about Scrooge, this was the perfect Tiny Tim.
*  The doorknocker. FINALLY! One that's true to the book!
*  Jacob Marley rocked. The best, ever. Dickens described the ghost of Marley as having an "atmosphere" about him and this movie displayed that.  This was great.
* A very good Ghost of Christmas Past. While this is quite different from what I had always pictured, I liked the interpretation.
* I'm in my late 50s and have been reading this book every year since I was a child (raised my children on that tradition), and have been disappointed with most movie characterizations of these main characters.  If it took "motion capture" to get there, then that's okay.  It works.
* The scenery was stellar.
* I have a blu-ray, so really enjoy the increased resolution. As expected, excellent Disney attention to detail.

The not so good:
* Miniaturizing Scrooge. Really?  Couldn't get past the silliness factor of that idea, especially since there seemed no plausible reason as to why it was necessary in the telling of the story.  How in the world was *that* true to what Dickens meant?
* The whole 3D thing was, in my opinion, somewhat overdone.  There are a lot of great parts that I feel were left out in favor of the 3D experiences which had nothing to do with the book.
*  The Ghost of Christmas Future had this whole Darth Vader-ish mojo going when they finally did a closeup of his face.
*  Considering the amount of detail and work put into the movie overall, I was surprised that the ending was so truncated.  Not *disappointed* because it was more accurate than Scrooge running around the floor with a rat (this *is* Disney, after all), but surprised.
* Little details of the book that somehow got either dropped or not fleshed out the way that I expected from a version that was supposed to be "very true to the spirit" of the book.

The unfleshed:
* Only one person in Old Joe's
* Fred's party
* Only one of the fund-raisers met with Scrooge after his experience
* Bob Cratchit speaking of meeting Scrooge's nephew after Tiny Tim's death
and a few others...

The deleted:
* The hearse up the stairs.
*  Scrooge's praises of Fezziwig
*  The complete breakup of Scrooge & Belle
*  Belle's family scene

There were several others, but these few scenes were very key to the telling of the story, and I feel that they were eliminated because of the 3D action gimmickry parts.

Overall, I felt that it was a very good interpretation of the book.  It may be a little scary for youngsters, but it *is,* after all, a Ghost story.  I found myself getting quite impatient with many of the parts made to emphasize the 3D effects (flying through the air over roofs and chimneys, getting stuck in the curtain rings, riding an icicle, etc.) because I felt that *some point* it detracted more than added to the quality of the movie.  I don't have a 3D tv yet, but I can see where it would be fun to watch. No, I didn't see the movie in the theaters.

I would definitely recommend the movie.  I can see it becoming a family tradition, especially if there are young children around.  I bought it to show to my grandchildren for the holidays for years to come.  Too bad there's not a version for adults.

Caveat Emptor on the 3D disc in this package.  Unlike "Coraline" and some other "3D" titles, the Blu Ray 3D Disc in this four disc package must be 1) played on a Blu Ray 3D player 2) played with a 3D High Definition Television and 3) Viewed with Special Cd glasses that come with either the TV, the Blu Ray player or bought separately.  Unless you have all three, you cannot view the 3D disc in this offering. Just wanted to eliminate any bad surprises anyone might encounter when trying to go 3D without all the right equipment. Otherwise, the regular Blu Ray disc is fantastic and I'm sure the regular DVD and Digital Copy for computers are great too. That's why it gets 5 stars from me.

The movie is wonderful and enjoyable however i would point out that it is not for appropriate all ages(parents need to determine if the movie is age appropriate for their childern and family. The move is darker than previous versions of the tale but more in tune with the book and the author(Charles Dickens)and the lesson in the story.

Having enjoyed numerous adaptations and original versions of this tale, we were extremely disappointed in this version. It must have been hard on Carrey to take that huge check when he had to endure such a horrible film. The sound was mediocre, the animation average, but the scenes were uninspired and flat. I have never been so bored as I was watching thisd movie. I tried to stay focused on some endearing or positive quality. I even felt pity for Tiny Tim's character, all but forgotten in this film.

I can really appreciate this film for its beauty - take any single frame and freeze it and it looks like an exquisite oil painting.  I also can appreciate that it stays very close to the original telling of the story.

That being said, I sat down to watch it with my 3 young children (ages 4,5, and 8) - and while they're not traumatized - had I reviewed it beforehand I wouldn't have had them watch this one.  I should have been more diligent, but I guess I was thinking "Disney" and trusted it.

Anyway - I enjoyed it, but for any other parents of small children you might want to watch it after they're in bed.

I WAS EXPECTING ALOT MORE FROM THIS MOVIE AFTER SEEING THE ADS AND KNOWING JIM CARREY WAS PART OF IT AND WITH THE ANIMATION. I WAS DISAPPOINTED WITH THE MOVIE.I HAVE SEEN OTHERS THAT WERE MUCH BETTER. IF I HAD SEEN IT PRIOR TO BUYING IT I WOULD NOT HAVE WASTED MY MONEY.

As a middle school reading teacher, I appreciate when I can show my students the movie version of a book.  As we are finishing up the classic piece of literature, A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens, I love that I can show this movie as an "unabridged" version of the literary work!
Good holiday film for the family.  Delivered fast, only disappointment was that I didn't realize it was in widescreen format.

This is a great video. The story is classic but this version is great in 3D. The effects are used as a way to give expression to the story and not just little effects that add nothing. My fear will 3D is that producers will feel the need to try to utilize effects that don't make the visual any better. This video gave depth and effects that just inhanced the overall effect of the story. This makes the purchase of my Panasonic 3D HDTV a good decision.

I expected a lot more from Disney and Carrey.  Of the 7 versions of "The Christmas Carol" that I own, this is the worst one.  I would not recommend it if you have ever watched and like the Christmas Carol movies.  But if you are into Halloween, you might like this one --- It felt a lot Halloweenish to me.

I was expecting to dislike this film. The trailers for it made it seem like sugar-coated ephemera with little relation to Charles Dickens' original novella. Thankfully, the publicity was misleading. Dickens' subtitle for his tale was "A Ghost Story." And indeed he filled his prose with deliciously grotesque descriptions of London's dark alleyways (think Jack the Ripper's Whitechapel), a brooding sense that Scrooge has long been due his comeuppance, and, of course, the ghosts themselves. This film doesn't shy away from these darker elements of the story and perhaps comes closer than any other version to capturing its suspense. (The one exception is the classic 1951 Scrooge, directed by Brian Desmond Hurst and starring Alistair Sim, with its atmospheric black-and-white cinematography.) On one hand, this is a plus for fans of the book. On the other hand, as with 2007's Bridge to Terabithia, parents unfamiliar with the source material may be misled into thinking the film is lighter than it actually is, resulting in much disgruntlement. I fall into the former category and was able to relish the film as a genuine ghost story. Unfortunately, I found the film's stylistic and cinematic finesse often came at the expense of narrative depth. The title sequence displays Zemeckis' eye for detail. He quite effectively evokes the Dickensian London: dirty, mean, teeming with life and social inequity. This is no idealized, picturesque Christmas town, but a city in the midst of an Industrial Revolution. Once the dialogue ensued, I was pleased to see the script was not watered-down for younger viewers, but borrows liberal chunks of Dickens' prose. Nuances in the text left out of other versions are presented here. We also see, for instance, Bob Cratchit "[go] down a slide on Cornhill, at the end of a lane of boys... in honour of its being Christmas Eve" and how "the fog and frost so hung about the black old gateway of [Scrooge's] house, that it seemed as if the Genius of the Weather sat in mournful meditation on the threshold." The performance capture cinematography itself can be quite stunning. Zemeckis' intention seems to have been to bring to life the classic illustrations of John Leech and Arthur Rackham as opposed to straight realism. The result is somewhat uneven. While some of the character designs seem strikingly realistic, others (like Scrooge himself) are exaggerated caricatures. It takes some time to adjust to this half-realistic, half-illustration approach. Jim Carrey's performance (as Scrooge and all three ghosts) is impressive in its range and ability to convey subtext. At points I feel he's let down by his age (or lack of it) when his voice doesn't quite convey the gravitas of years of loneliness. At other points, elements of his shtick poke through in Scrooge's face and mannerism. Although such moments break up the heaviness of much of the film, it sometimes seems anachronistic. Overall, however, he lends genuine depth and pathos to Scrooge and mirth with a slight undertone of grim seriousness to the Ghost of Christmas Present. One misstep in the design is Jacob Marley's Ghost, which I found more hokey than frightening. Gary Oldman's voice performance is certainly no patch on the hair-raising portrayals of Michael Hordern (1951) or Frank Finlay (opposite George C. Scott in the brilliant 1984 television version). But the three Spirits of Christmas are imaginatively done. This may just be the first time the Ghost of Christmas Past has been depicted as Dickens described him, dunce cap and all. The Ghost of Christmas Present's aging is quite effective, evoking elements of symbolism lacking in other versions. The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come gets an interesting treatment, emerging out of Scrooge's own shadow. Also of special note is the musical score by Alan Silvestri which incorporates traditional Christmas carols at key moments. At points, the music can be a little overwrought, insisting too emphatically that the audience notice aspects of the unfolding drama that might be better accompanied by silence, but generally Silvestri alternates between festive buoyancy and ghostly suspense quite effectively. All that said, the film unfortunately wastes a lot of time on gratuitous scenes that do nothing to advance Dickens' story and exist solely to justify the 3D experience for moviegoers. I wouldn't have a problem with this (the scenes are thrilling enough on my moderately large HDTV; I can imagine they'd be amazing on the big screen in 3D), except that these scenes often come at the expense of narrative. As faithful as the screenplay is in places, a lot of good material is sacrificed for scenes in which Scrooge is flying, falling, or fleeing for no apparent reason. The most conspicuous is one other reviewers have mentioned: a large chunk of the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come sequence is devoted to a scene in which Scrooge is chased by a black hearse. On one hand, this underscores the fact that Scrooge does not have many Christmases left. On the other hand, the scene was several minutes long and wastes valuable time that could have been spent on a touching moment from the book in which Bob Cratchit mentions having met Scrooge's nephew Fred at Tiny Tim's grave site. The result? The characterization loses out much of the time to the visuals. The scenes depicting Ebenezer's past and fall into his present miserly loneliness and those featuring the Cratchit family at home, for instance, feel much less developed than in other versions. Tiny Tim himself, the subject of much anxiety and affection in the original novella, gets almost no treatment here at all beyond his obligatory "God bless us, everyone." This lack of characterization is what prevents this version and Carrey's Scrooge, impressive and insightful as it is, from becoming as iconic as Sim or Scott or Patrick Stewart in his one-man audio version or even Michael Caine in the surprisingly faithful Muppet version. With all the attention paid to the stunning 3D effects, Carrey's Scrooge doesn't get the opportunity to be fleshed out into all of its three dimensions. Less time devoted to scenes extraneous to the action and more devoted to the preliminary damning and ultimate reclamation of his soul (the terms in which Dickens described this story), and we could had something more substantial. It's definitely not a lost opportunity. What's here is engaging and often gripping, but I didn't get the sense of catharsis I had with more dialogue-driven (as opposed to visual-driven) versions of the work. If Amazon would let me, I'd rate it 3.5 stars.

I don't want to ruin this movie for anyone. If you have not seen this version of A Christmas Carol, purchase it now! The visual imagery is spectacular! Be forewarned, I personally do not think this version is appropriate for children as it is very heavy, dark and a bit scary. Overall, I think it captures the spirit of Dickens' original work, leaving nothing out. Some may say Robert Zemeckis took too much artistic liberty with Dickens work but I staunchly disagree. The ghosts held up the mirror squarely to Scrooge's face and he had to accept his failures and the very possible consequences of continuing down the path he was currently on. the bestpart of it all though is the fact that much of Dickens' original dialogue from the books are spoken through out the movie. Kudos Jim Cary and Mr. Zemeckis!

I thought this movie was pretty good. Don't really understand why there are so many negative reviews about this movie. I understand that some people were upset cause they thought this was a kid movie, but it does have a PG rating which is a warning to keep little kids away. I thought it was well done and worth watching, now buying at full price, not so much. Maybe when it drops down some.
This movie has become one of my most favorites! I am a big Jim Carrey fan, and this movie was exceptional! This is a must have for people of all ages!

The animation is great...however for younger children this movie is hard to understand.  Some parts of the story were quite scary and I don't know why they had to go so far as to have the ghost of Jacob Marley's jaw break apart and what's with the ghost of Christmas present and those scary looking horses?  I was hoping for a Christmas movie that we would want to watch over and over again, unfortunately we watched it once and now it's collecting dust.  Again this is totally my opinion, someone else might love this movie.  My 3 (out of 5) children watched it, their ages are 10, 5 and 4.  My ten year old son had a lot of questions, things didn't make sense like the scene with the 2 nasty looking children that hang around the feet of one of the ghosts.  So just be prepared, I was even scratching my head thinking, "what.."  Hope this review helps you, have a Merry Christmas.

Zemeckis strikes again, better than expected! At first when I started to watch this, I did not know it was "animated" (not cartoon animation, but "real animation") and said to myself "ahhh I hate animated movies, the actors don't have to act, they only need their voices". BOY was I WRONG!! As I continued to watch the movie I thoroughly enjoyed it, the closest to Charles Dickens true story I've seen in this old classic. After watching the entire movie I went to the "extras" and watched how they put this movie together. I found that in my error, the actors have to be exceptional, outstanding, with a great imagination to pull off this movie. Every movement/facial expression is done by the actor himself, not just "animation". Jim Carrey as always is amazing, but the rest of the cast is outstanding also (Gary Oldman, Colin Firth, Carey Elwes). Gary Oldman as the ghost of Jacob Marley is genius! I am truly happy that I purchased this movie on a whim, as it is the best "A Christmas Carol" I've seen and I've seen probably most.  Do yourself a favor, treat yourself to this wonderful classic, you will not be dissapointed. Excellent.
~from a hardcore film buff

I can pretty much sum up my opinion of this movie up by my reaction to the long, drawn out, adrenaline-packed action sequence that is de rigueur in animated movies, in this case in Christmas Future when Scrooge is being chased by the giant black horses down the streets and down more streets and down even more streets and down yet even more streets and finally down the sewer: is there a point to this and is it ever gonna end? And the Ghost of Christmas Present with his incessant booming laugh is the most annoying character since Jar Jar Binks. The characters and storyline are two-dimensional, and are only there to justify one heavy-handed dramatic scene after another. If you must see it, rent it for a buck ninety-nine at Red Box and be glad afterward that you didn't pay full price for it.

the most bizarre, unsettling Christmas movie I have ever seen.  After Carey did The Grinch I was expecting MUCH more than what I got.  This version is too scary for little kids and not worth your money. I wish I could return it.  It WAS THAT BAD.
I liked all aspects of this movie. I have seen at least 5 versions of this movie and I liked this probably the best. 3D puts you in the movie. This is our favorite 3D movie. Enjoy.

I have purchased two copies of this dvd and one was from wal-mart.com and today I received a copy from Disney dvd club. Neither one of the 3d discs will work. I have the samsung 3d tv,3d blueray player, so I have the right equipment but cannot get it to play. And off course Disney customer service is only open when everyone else is working. The regular discs work fine. Can any give me some suggestions?

I was excited to watch this on DVD and was thinking about buying it.  Glad I waited to watch it first.  Honestly, they made Scrooge so grotesque, I had trouble even wanting to look at his face.  Not a good way to start off a movie.  And it was very morbid, very vivid and went over the top on anything that could be the least bit scary.  This is a horror movie.  It's great if you like that kind of thing, but I much prefer to have a little bit of Christmas cheer mixed into A Christmas Carol.  Yes, the storyline does have ghosts and scary parts in all versions, but this would definitely terrify children.  After about 25 minutes in, my husband begged me to please turn it off and we put on one of my favorites, The Muppet's Christmas Carol which is just brilliant, heart warming, funny, pleasant to watch and has great music as well.  I recommend that one over this any day.  I can't imagine even wanting to see the entire thing.

Nothing can beat its a Wonderful Life, but this comes really close.

I was amazed by the story line, graphics, and Carrey's performance.  Scrooge is rotten to the core and in the end becomes a great man through his conversion.  Loved every minute of it.

It's what you would expect from Disney these days.  It's a little too graphic for young children and they may not catch what is actually going on.  I viewed this with my children and they could not sleep at night.  Really removes the joy of Christmas. NOT FOR YOUNG CHILDREN!!!!

When I saw this in the movies, I honestly wasn't so impressed with it. The movie itself has a feeling of redundancy. This story, while one of my favorites, has been done to death. And yes, in case you're wondering, I DID see it in 3D in the theatre. When I purchased this on 3D Blu-ray(solely due to lack of 3D Blu content so far), I was MUCH more impressed with the 3D at home. It just seemed to pop more. For those who are unfamiliar with the tale(i.e. small children), the movie will be a treat. If you own a 3D TV, this is a MUST HAVE, DEMO MATERIAL disc, no matter if the movie itself is merely good. Recommended!!!

I don't do many reviews but this movie was so bad that I had to. So many unnecessary and stupid variations from the original story. Dark would be OK but most of the dark parts were just plain stupid. Marley's mouth dropping open, Scrooge chased by red eyed horses, sliding on a chunk of ice and shrunk to miniature size? What? Just awful. This was a chance for Disney and the director to use the technology to enhance the story but it misses on so many levels.

I really thought this version of A Christmas Carol was the best one. I espescially loved how they delved into the dark side of Scrooge and made his experience extra cathartic. I guess those who gave this film a negitive review just can't handle a realistic version.

This was without doubt the worst version of "A Christmas Carol" I've ever seen. Even the cartoon Scrooge McDuck version was better than this.

The presentation of Scrooge was dismal beyond any sense of proportion. The extended chin and nose were so blatently overdone, it was embarrassing. And the development of these features, from childhood to young adult to middle age, was over the top outrageous.

Bob Cratchit and the Ghost of Christmas Past were poorly conceived and presented. The race with the hearse was way to long and is no where within the original story.

Were there any redeeming features? Well yes a couple. The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come was well conceived. Furthermore, the overhead travels across London were well done.

Nonetheless, this version of "A Christmas Carol" isn't worth the time nor money.

This story is a classic and has been done to death in both live action and animated versions. I am a stalwart fan of the story though and of course gave this version a go ...... I mean it's Disney, how bad could it be? So there I am not expecting too much only to find that this is the definitive version for all those that love this time honoured story. It is visually beautiful and not a little disturbing that you have to keep reminding yourself that the characters are computer generated, especially Scrooge himself, brilliantly voiced by Jim Carrey. In fact, it has a stellar voice cast including Gary Oldman, Bob Hoskins and my personal favourite, Colin Firth. It is as faithful to the original tale as any I have seen and will leave you feeling good and really, isn't that what you want out of a Christmas movie.  A word of caution to parents of young children though, say five and under, some of the imagery could lead to Christmas nightmares rather than Christmas dreams.

This movie was straight up just horrible and such a disappointment out of Disney.  I am so thankful that my boys were no where around when we watched this.  It seemed to drag on FOREVER and it had very frightening images.  Don't waste your time.  Watch the muppets or mickey's xmas carol.  Skip this one altogether.

I Love this Movie, I think the Actors did a very nice Job with syncing there voices to the screen in 3D this Is absolutly Amazing I thought the Whole 3D experience was Great through the movie I cannot say one bad word about it.. if you have a 3D HDTV 1080p and Love the christmas Carrol, Get this movie.. it is worth it. I saw it in 2d and still thought it was a good movie.. 5 stars

I saw this film finally almost one year later since it's release in the theaters.  I can only say that I am so thankful there is Redbox and I only spend $1 for my entire family to see this movie as anything more than that would have been wasteful use of my resources! I almost turned the movie off a dozen times 6 times because of the perversion they created which is not for young childrens minds and 6 times because I felt I wasting my precious time! The pseudo camera perspective was insane and the use of special effects was only because they could do it like changing Scrooge in a tiny man who could slide down a drain gutter.  This movie made no sense and either Jim Carrey has gone off the deep end or had no say in the making of this movie! Do not buy this movie unless you love twisted perversion! I feel sorry for all the poor souls who are fans of Jim Carrey and who spent $20 for a ticket, popcorn, and Coke last year.  I suspect the popcorn and Coke was for once a good deal in comparison to the theater ticket!

This is a great CHRISTMAS addition to a video library. The special features are great. My only negative about it is how long it takes to load and access the special features on the blue ray disc. This particular movie is special to me as it was the last movie I saw with my Dad before his passing away.

Like other reviewers of this movie I was expecting something special from Disney with an old classic.  While the animation graphics are very detailed and impressive, the movie is not interesting or entertaining.  I have other previous  representations of A Christmas Carol that I have enjoyed watching over and over.  I can see no reason to put myself through another viewing of this one.  Also, I strongly recommend not showing this to younger children (older children will be totally disinterested).  I feel it very inappropriate for young children which is surprising considering it is a Disney product.

This movies was not made to promote Christmas but to destroy it... Yes its got cool special effects and it has a good message at the end, but its the hidden message in the middle that everyone needs to be aware of... The second ghost is a sick representation of santa/jesus figure who looks and acts kind of evil/demented drunk Guy "and if you don't think so just look at the beard, his hair, HIS CROWN OF THORNS & the Religious music playing in the background... But this jesus/santa figure dies a sudden and disturbing death... Since when does the second ghost die in the original story and why would this Movie make such a horrible evil looking second ghost that mocks christmas or Jesus... Oh unless if its written and produced by a Zionist/Talumdic Jew... I guess I answered my own question... Please Christians Wake Up and stay away from evil movies like this that are out to destroy what's left of Christmas... Nick

PS: I am not mocking disney "Walt Disney was a christian" but not today its run my Talmudic Jews like most of hollywood...

Horrible attempt at the classic. I thought this would be good for all the actors in it and it was VERY disappointing. Couldn't even finish it, it was so bad. Half the time you can't understand what Jim Carey's character is even saying.

Wow, can't believe there are still major movies like this with out any African-American characters in them. How do you make a movie with this many characters and' not one minority of any sort in it. Shame on Jim Carrey for allowing that. After all it was only the Wayan Brothers, (two black guys) that made him famous. Nobody knew who he was until, In living Color. And by the way the movie sucked, definitely not for kids. Waste of money

Wow, can't believe there are still major movies like this with out any African-American characters in them. How do you make a movie with this many characters and' not one minority of any sort in it. Shame on Jim Carrey for allowing that. After all it was only the Wayan Brothers, (two black guys) that made him famous. Nobody knew who he was until, In living Color. And by the way the movie sucked, definitely not for kids. Waste of money
If you own a 3D tv this is the DVD you have been waiting for to show it off!  I had heard Zemeckis had done a great job using the technology but this is awesome!  Definitely a must  have.

This was a relatively faithful adaptation of the Charles Dicken's Christmas classic with a few seemingly added-just-for-3D visual sequences that were both annoying and slightly nauseating when watched in the non-3D Blu-Ray version.

My problem with the movie is that the last thing we need is another faithful movie rendition of "A Christmas Carol," perhaps the most filmed story of all time. I was expecting a Disney twist and, I admit, a bit of kid-friendly magic, a la Robert Zemeckis' endlessly charming "Polar Express," and instead got Dicksonian-prose (baffling to most children and many adults) and the occasional uninspired 3D shot, clearly done just for the wow-look-at-that effect. (The shrinking to mouse-size scene was nonsensical, never explained, and clearly done solely to add in some more 3D moments.)

My son was bored and occasionally frightened and I didn't see any point in using name-above-the-title star Jim Carrey, whom I usually despise, but here just found totally generic. (Again, unlike Tom Hanks, who inhabited every role he portrayed in "Polar Express.") There may have been much Carrey-esque scene munching and physical angst during the motion capture shoot that created this movie, but little of it comes through in the final onscreen product, which I found dull and not even touching, the very thing the original story excels so well at and why it's been a relevant tale for close to two hundred years.

Tiny Tim is barely introduced, and only fleetingly referred to, so our feeling for his disappearance in Christmas future is limited--thus missing the heart and soul of Dicken's story--and Scrooge's redemption is rushed and not at all believable. He seems not a changed man, but rather a still-bitter man now frightened into acts of kindness by an impending demise that never before occurred to him, apparently, despite his wildly advanced age.

Taken solely as an animated adaption of Dicken's tale, the movie is so-so, with a fairly faithful plot line, but with little to appeal to children outside the high-tech computer animation. As a Disney movie, the entire effort falls flat and even the much dated, far lower budget, "Mickey's Christmas Carol" does a much better job of introducing the story and entertaining younger children. This Carol just wasn't very special, and definitely not deserving of the Disney name. A big miss for me and my family.

I have to say this new version of an old classic is by far my new Christmas favorite.  I think the animation is off the chart and it is very well done.  I think that Jim Carrey was a great addition to this movie and it sets the bar for many other animated features to come.  Great movie
Its a decent movie....for adults. I have a 7 year old who has seen all of the pirates of the carabean movies and was not scared by them but I will not let him watch this one, its to scary.

I thought this movie had a few great 3D moments which made great viewing. Exactly the reason why I bought a 3D TV for Home. But, the movie itself I thought was not suited for the PG rating it's given. My 6 & 7year old boys can watch Iron Man 1 & 2 and understand the plot / storyline. With this movie they were forever asking "Whats going on Dad...". Great graphics, good storyline, but dialogue not designed for children under 13. Extra star given for the 3D effects.

I just finished watching this for the first time and I was rather dissapointed in it. I think Disney could have done a better job and it was hard for me to sit all the way through. Unlike most of Disney's movies I wasn't able to really get into this classic tale and I found it rather dull and for my tastes to dark in some parts of the movie.

The presentation follows the formula and the dialog follows the formula. There is nothing wrong with different interpret ions of this Charles dickens classic. Yet there is nothing unique enough to justify this version. It is just a hum-bug. You may be better off reading the book. This story was made as much for children as "Alice in Wonderland."

Now if they could have hired the actors to act instead of just twisted versions of their voices, we may have a good movie. If you think that the cheap flashy animation will make it more palatable for children, you may want to rethink. The presentation would have to be morphed in to one of those watered down cutesy things that Disney is noted for. This Marley looks like it was designed by John Carpenter.

Anyway it passes time and if it was the only version you own then it will do.

Scrooge, and ill tempered spend thrift is awaked to his social duty by three ghosts that visit him on Christmas Eve. Who will get the spirit of Christmas, and who will get the goose? (O.K. turkey)

I only saw the Blu-ray version so I cannot compare. There were the standard coming attractions trouncing 3D. The DVD extras include behind the scenes where they took the time to put dots on actors (motion capture) yet could have just made it as well with CGI.  There is a tutorial on Disney digital 3D.

Slow, uneventful, and LOUD.  I was hoping that I could add this to the family collection of holiday movie traditions, but I was very dissappointed.  If you're going to tell such a familiar story as this, it better hold my interest and move quicker.  As one reviewer said, I didn't connect with the characters either.  I actually fell asleep at the beginning, only to be woken up by ghost Marley's howling and chain shaking.  Didn't finish and don't feel like I missed out by doing so.  Spend your money getting Polar Express on bluray instead.

This film was a disappointment, especially given that it was helmed by one of Hollywood's best directors, Robert Zemeckis. Most people are probably aware of Charles Dickens classic story about an embittered old man being visited by three ghosts on Christmas Eve in a final attempt to salvage his humanity. Most of us eagerly anticipate the latest revisioning of this beloved tale, but its success or failure depends on if we emotionally connect to the characters enough to share in Scrooge's warm and fuzzy transformation at the end of the tale. There were some interesting riffs off old ideas, but unfortunately this version simply didn't work for me. The style of animation was weirdly cold and artificial - it felt like watching someone play a "Christmas Carol" game on Xbox or PS3. Too bad Disney didn't tap Pixar for this. The end of the visitation by the ghost of Christmas Present added to the overall macabre vibe. This story has many superior previous versions, including the classic A Christmas Carol [Blu-ray] and the often maligned Scrooge
A Christmas Carol with Jim Carrey is beautifully animated and has a great moral, even though it is not kid-friendly!  I love it!

Every year I look forward to watching  A Christmas Carol and over the years have watched many renditions of Charles Dickson's famous classic but this version is by and far the worst I've ever seen. I eagerly awaited Disney's version and had high expectations since Jim Carey was the voice of Scrooge. As I watched Disney's version I had a hard time staying awake, and my sister who was also watching, or should I say tried to watch, this version fell asleep half way through the movie. I found it difficult to connect with the characters and found the "spirit" of A Christmas Carol to be lost.

I give this movie a lower rating not because of the wonderful visual affects or the great backgrounds of the 1800's. No, I give it a lower rating because there are scenes in there that I believe are NOT appropriate for younger children. This movie has "scary" moments as well as characters for little minds. I don't believe that because our children have grown up in the age of technology that they should experience this at an earlier age.  Anyway, back to what I was saying.... of course the last ghost - death I believe it is is suppose to be dark. However, that ghost has some characters that tag along with him, black horses with red eye and a black carriage. My son of 8 looked at me and said " mom, I think this is suppose to be a Halloween movie". He took the words right out of my mouth.

The makers of this movie are going for the wow factor and they got it however I will NOT be telling friends to rent this with their 3 yr old around or any children under 6 or 7. Disney, you should be ashamed!

All in all, same story- nice to look at visually and I am sure it will be splendid on Blue Ray too.
A rich classic has been vandalized.  The audio was hard to listen to, the storyline was dark and it served no purpose to the movie.  A total waste of time as far as I was concerned.

When I heard Jim Carrey was going to voice Scrooge I feared that he would make the character over the top.  Well that was completely unfounded as Carrey gives an utterly amazing performance. It is understated and just perfectly captures the character.  The Blu Ray 3D effects are pretty much the same as in the theatrical version.  They never overshadow the movie but instead add depth and beauty to it. Really an instant classic.

A Christmas Carol is over 160 years old, and it's still going strong. I bet Charles Dickens would be proud. This movie is visually beautiful and has amazing scenery. Jim Carrey does a great job at playing Ebenezer Scrooge, who wants nothing to do with Christmas, forces Bob Cratchit to work on Christmas day, and refuses to go to his nephew's Christmas dinner party. On Christmas Eve, Scrooge is visited by his dead partner, Marley that tells him that he will be visited by 3 ghosts who try to change Scrooge's outlook on Christmas. Christmas Past shows him how Scrooge came to be who he was, Present shows him that his nephew feels sorry for him and that Cratchit's family don't have enough money to afford a meal, and the Future shows him what tragedies will happen unless Scrooge changes his ways. I highly recommend A CHRISTMAS CAROL!!!

I'm a fan of all Christmas Carol adaptations, even the Muppet one, and at the beginning of this movie I thought "wow, this could really be good" but it turned out to be disappointing.

The problem I have with the movie, just my personal opinion, is it tries to alternate between serious scenes and slapstick humor and the mix just doesn't work (for me). Some scenes are recreated in a serious, dramatic way that really convey the spirit of the book.  The passing scenes of 19th century London life add a lot of atmosphere and Carrey does a great (serious) job with the voices.  Then - bam! - some visual gag is thrown in that's reminiscent of Carrey's physical comedy in other movies or a Bugs Bunny cartoon and you're thinking "where did that come from?"; then just as abruptly it switches back to the standard dramatic story.  The physical comedy might work for little kids but the movie also has some scenes that are too scary/disturbing for young children, so who exactly is their audience?  The last straw for me was a chase scene (really, a chase scene) that was clearly thrown in to show off the particle/water/physics effects of their animation engine, as if we haven't all seen enough animated water by now; you could almost hear the programmers saying "oh! oh! can we throw this in, it will look so cool."

If it was supposed to be a comedy, it should have been lighthearted throughout.  If it was supposed to demonstrate that they could make a great Christmas Carol using animation (which they could have) they should have left out the shtick.

The technical wizardry of Robert Zemeckis and crew is on the forefront of this very effective and entertaining film. Jim Carey performs Scrooge and other characters with his usual flamboyance, although not with his usual humor, as humor is not germane to the story. Rather the performances are domintaed by the shockingly stunning and beautiful animation. I viewed the film on blu-ray and I simply don't have the words to effectively describe how good this film is technically. It is surprisingly faithful to the Dicken's original, incorporating some scenes that have to my knowledege not made it into other movie versions. My only criticism of the film regards the scenes involving the Ghost of Christmas Future. The segment is a bit over-long, ultra-harrowing, and for that reason, not appropriate for young children, although the rest of the film is. It is fascinating and ironic that it has taken a state of the art 21st century movie rendition of the book to so accurately capture what Dickens was describing in the 19th century. Special features are adequate, describing the motion-capture technology behind the lustrous animation.

I was very excited to see this movie on blu-ray 3D, and never saw it in theaters. I have watched and have many other 3D titles. This was the worst 3D experience I have had yet in terms of the picture 3D quality. There was a lot of double vision, making the picture not as crisp. I am not sure it it was my Samsung LN46C750 46-Inch 1080p 3D LCD HDTV or the movie it self. And the movie has a ton of dark or black scenes, which looked bad too, like white cloudy areas on my screen; maybe my TV? I have never noticed this before now though on any other movies. The movie was like I remember the older movies/stories. The story moved slow and not that exciting, I was hopeful they changed it up a bit. But not bad. I was amazed my the detail in the characters in this movie compared to other animated movies, it really looked great! My main issue was the picture quality. POOR. I would be interesting in others experience in the picture quality

My equipment:
*Samsung LN46C750 46-Inch 1080p 3D LCD HDTV
*Samsung BD-C6900 1080p 3D Blu-ray Disc Player
*Onkyo HT-S3300 Home Theater System

PRICE: I pre-ordered months ago on Amazon for $27.99 and as it was being shipped to me I find the $10 Disney coupon for it. Wal-mart and other stores locally had the same price, but after contacting Amazon they gave me a $10 credit. So all said and done I paid $17.99 w/ free shipping!

I suppose that everyone looks for different things in movies... This has to be one of the worst diologue audio mixes that i have tried to listen to in recent years!!!  Yes you can turn the audio up to try to listen to it --- until the next scene blows you out of the room.... This is ultimately annoying... On the other hand most of the movie is acceptable-- But how mutch laughter can you take from christmas present???  3 stars...
I wish I would have rented this before buying it because I would not have wasted my money.  Truly disappointed in Disney and Jim Carrey needs to stick to comedy.

Movie snobs may laugh...but I think this movie is an absolute masterpiece of cinema.  Never has there been such foreboding in ANY of the previous versions...the Ghost Of Christmas Yet To Come is the most stunning visualization ever.  Such powerful use of...silence.

Hauntingly beautiful, the BlueRay version is something you will be playing generations from now.  I saw it in the theatre in 3D and was blown away, so I was a little wary that it may not have the same impact on the small screen...I was wrong.

I used to count the 1984 (made for T.V.) George C. Scott version as my favorite(with the 1951 Alistair Sim version a VERY close second)...I now have a new favorite!

This in my opinion is the best cinema version of Charles Dickens A Christmas Carol to date.  The story stays very close the original version and really brings brings it to life with the 3d motion capture.  The ghosts are superb, the acting is top notch and Jim Carrey makes a great scrooge.  I went into this movie thinking I would hate it but I was thankfully dead wrong, I left knowing I was going to buy it on DVD as soon as it came out, it is an instant holiday classic for me.  I watched the blu ray  the other night and it looked great, now I want to get a 3D tv so I can check out the 3d version of the movie.

I have never written a review after having been an Amazon customer for over 8 years now at least, however, after seeing the dreadful amount of reviews for the movie, I had to make sure I gave it a 5 star review.  I consider myself a "Christmas Carol" movie buff (of my own making of course), and this version is so close to perfect that it deserves the highest of all reviews.  For those who say that this was meant to be an uplifting story and is too 'scary', I suppose you have never taken the time to read the book.  It is a story of redemption, and of turning a miserable miser into a completely uplifted new man.  A man that was given a second chance at life...and I am sorry, but it would have sickened me to see them portray this otherwise.  In order for man to change, they must see their wrongs and the repercussions that will happen if life is continued being lived without care of others, and this is exactly what Dicken's was portraying, and what the movie came across as. To see it all 'fluffed' up and 'Disney'd' up would just be ridiculing what Dicken's was trying to prove.  I personally love the version with George C. Scott, as well as the classic with Alastair Sim, but when I saw this first last year, I knew that there was a new classic.  All the parts, minor as they may be, that have been left out of previous versions were included, and I thought that this movie hit the book to the 't' and am so glad to have this movie to pass down to others, to show what the book was truly supposed to be like when coming to life in Hollywood.  For those who feel it is too scary, I suggest you show your children Sesame Street or something of the like, because I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but guess what?  Life is not always good, sometimes it can be downright harsh....and this movie put to life what happens when a man who has been a terrible person both inside his heart and out gets a chance at redemption...a second chance to live, and if this is not something your children may understand at their young age, then you may want to just put this on the shelf for a few more years until they realize that life is not full of marshmallows and happiness 24 hours a day....otherwise, sit down and enjoy the movie of a lifetime!

Hey everyone, well I really wanted to like this movie... however it was just to weird... funny at very very few parts.... Sorry Disney my family gives this movie.. 2 out of 5 stars!!! This Christmas Carol Movie went very wrong!!!!

For the past 40-odd years, my standard in filmed versions of Charles Dickens "A Christmas Carol" has been the Alastair Sim version from 1951. That remains my standard to this day.

Based on 1983's unsuccessful "Mickey's Christmas Carol," I was prepared for Disney to once again screw up this classic tale with "Disney's A Christmas Carol." Jim Carrey's name emblazoned across the 3-sheets added to the sense of trepidation.

Well, I was wrong. Quite wrong, to be honest about it. This is an excellent version of Dickens' classic tale, a version that hews much closer to the book than most other versions out there, including my beloved Sim version. The fantasy elements are here given the room to be fantastic, which really works if one believes that Scrooge's journey to redemption may well have happened in his dreams, rather than in the here and now (pace Mr Dickens' admonition to his readers concerning the veracity of his tale).

Jim Carrey voices and acts most of the main characters in this version, and he's very good at creating unique characterizations that really delineate the players from each other. He is masterful in his portrayal of the Ghost of Christmas Past, somehow speaking in a way that one would imagine a flame would speak had it voice to do so. His Ghost of Christmas Present is also good, a larger-than-life figure who stands in stark contrast to Scrooge's disconnected-from-humanity self. Carrey's Scrooge is - dare I say it - loaded with subtleties that I really didn't expect from him. His voice characterization is spot on, and SO much closer to what one would expect from a faithful rendition of what Dickens penned than say, the disastrous performance of George C. Scott in his 1980's TV version of the tale.

Credit is also due to Gary Oldman's portrayal of Bob Cratchit and - even more so - his Ghost of Jacob Marley, which has to be seen to be believed. One cannot imagine a truer version of Dickens' vision than that achieved in this film's combination of acting, motion capture and animation. Spooky and VERY convincing.

The only caveat I'll voice about the movie concerns a couple of extended "action sequences" that were included to no doubt keep the teens and tweens engrossed in the film. Most egregious among these is the scene where Scrooge is chased through the streets of London by a hellish Ciste Bodhar. It really adds nothing to the story, even if the animation is particularly good.

Not everyone is a fan of motion-capture technology, but I feel it serves this film well, bridging the gap between live-action and animation versions of the story and maybe coming away with the best of both worlds. Robert Zemeckis and crew have gained expertise in their use of the technique since "The Polar Express," and it pays dividends here.

The extras included are very interesting, especially a feature that takes us behind the scenes to see just how the motion-capture technology is put to the service of the film makers.

So this is well worth owning, even if it does get numerous plays on various TV channels during the season and - strangely - throughout the rest of the year as well. As a bonus, the singing of the song "God Bless Us, Every One" by the highly overrated Andrea Bocelli is limited to the credit run at the end of the film, so you can simply avoid having to hear it at all without missing a minute of the film itself!

Four stars - excellent, but just a cut below my above-declared standard in "A Christmas Carol" movies.

mines a little shorter than most; this is visually perfect! it is a true dark account of the meaning Dickens wanted to tell. misery on several levels, nobody was happy; even scrooge's nephew had his own worries, even if putting on a good face. true, not for kids; marley? kids don't need that! very darkly filmed; should give way to how the story unfolds. this is the ADULT film version, give children something of a lighter version. we thoroughly enjoyed this; yet not something to view over and over....to us, anyway.  FIVE STARS!

"A Christmas Carol" is my all time favorite story.  I have seen every version ever made including most plays.  This is an over the top Jim Carey movie.  I watched it with my 7yr old grandson and he was so scared he couldn't sleep. All the horror took away from the moral of the story. It makes me very angry that Disney was a part of this. One of the most impressively effective and beautiful 3D movies ever rendered for the new 3D generation.

I have to say that I saw this movie in 3D at theaters.. and it was ok. I say that because I thoroughly enjoyed it, but didn't think the 3D was as phenomenal as other films. I was hesitant to purchase it again on Bluray-3D simply for this fact, but got it through Amazon's Disney discount offer, which made the purchase at a value. Wow, was I wrong with the 3D effects.

The movie looks GORGEOUS on my 3D television. The story is amazingly well done, if not a bit creepy in some parts. It does push the boundaries of a PG film. Some parts, especially the Jacob Marley and third ghost of Christmas Future, are almost too frightening for small children, especially in 3D. But older kids (~8-10 yrs old) would probably love it, even if they do not understand what is being said. The movie uses almost exact prose from the Dickens masterpiece, therefore adults would understand the speech more than their children- after all, the original story by Mr. Charles was written as a ghost story intended for adults rather than for children. The underlying themes and ideas are great for all ages, but better understood and directed towards the lives of adults in this corruptive world that we live in.

Pay no mind to the harsh reviews of others here on Amazon, the movie is excellent. A classic! Jim Carrey truly delivers his best performance, something that my father will watch and be impressed to know that it is actually the goofy, suggestive man that he once despised as Ace Ventura. A redeeming performance on his behalf for a movie of redemption during the holiday season. Zemeckis adds his eye-candy flavor to an already well-established tale to make this a fun and rewarding experience that rivals other holiday films for the best movie to enjoy next to a crackling fire on Christmas Eve. Oscar-worthy performances by all, especially Carrey. Rewarding 3D effects that truly immerse you into the adventure. Well worth its place in everyone's holiday collection. Easily five stars.

I saw this movie in 3D last year and really enjoyed it.  So, I was really glad to see it finally on Blu-ray! I have watched it twice since I bought it yesterday.  The Blu-ray quality is excellent.  If you love Christmas movies then you need to see this movie.

I took my daughter to see this movie in the theater last year. I was so pleasently surprised that Disney actually stuck to the original story with this film. It held all the humor AND the darkness of the book. Be aware that as this does follow the book, it may not be appropriate for small children. Dickens can be very dark, and scary for young ones.

I don't often leave reviews for movies but this one I really enjoyed when I saw it with my husband last year right before Christmas. I was very impressed with the animation, you can practically see Jim Carrey's eyes starring out from Scrooge's face! I mean talk about very expressive animation! And I've always loved A Christmas Carol for the story, such a wonderful redemption story.

I have to say though that I was very surprised at some parts of this movie. Considering that it was rated PG I wasn't expecting some of the things to be in there that were in there. It had some very disturbing scenes in there that I would not recommend for small children. And while I've added this to our Christmas collection for when we do have kids I'm going to wait for my kids to be a bit older to see this one. But I still enjoyed it very much. Jim Carrey definitely delivered another amazing performance.

I had high hopes for this movie. I expect when I watch an animated movie from Disney with my children about Christmas I do not need to screen it ahead of time. I was appaled at how scary they made this movie. Did they really need to have Marley's jaw come unhinged and flop around..and his face rearrange. This movie scared the hell out of my 7 and 5 year old children. They said it should be called a Halloween Carol. To me it was just boring. I was so disappointed and ultimately a little angry that I had to spend the night up with my children who had nightmares over it.
I would not recommend this to children under 10 at all. From now on I will make sure I either watch it first or clear it with a friend that it is ok. It is a shame I have to do that with a cartoon. I was expected something warm and uplifting, like the Polar Express. This was the opposite of that. I HATED it.
Awsome 3D effects,great clarity/bright,sound is exellent. Can't wait for Avitar which in my opinion was blurry and dark in 3D at the theater,but still good. 1080p will be much better.
Although we are familiar with this story/movie, you must pick up this copy. The graphics are great, and the movie is fun to watch with your kids!

First of all this review is for the 2 disc Blu-ray/DVD release. I saw this first in theaters, I was amazed at not only the story and digital effect, but the 3D. Disney's A Christmas Carol is by far has the best 3D effects I ever have seen. I wondered if the thrill would transfer to 2D. It did, although there is certain scenes that look a bit off obviously added just for the 3D effect. I was supprised at the bonus features. They were about all a fan of this film could expect or want they follow:
Picture in Picture: by far the best special feature on the disc. It shows the actors as they filmed the movie, black dot's and all.

Commentary:  This is meant to go along with the PIP, but it is optional. Zemeckis' commentary is a little borning but still worth the lisen.

Countdown to Christmas:A frustrating advent calender.

Capturing Dickens:  A short documenty(hosted by a VERY annoying woman) it's informative but a little too short.

On set with Sammi: a featurette were one of the cast members tell us about motion capture

Deleted Scenes: Deleted scenes obviously. They are good and a little fun to watch

Overall I would say that the special features are rather good. The only bad thing I can say is they obsess over Motion Capture too much(We get it's Motion Capture Robert)

Good Movie, although I would think twice before letting little children view it,It's probably the scariest version of A Christmas Carol ever filmed.

Let me start off by saying I love Christmas movies, almost all of them.  So I went to the theatre with high hopes but was quickly let down.  Being Disney and having Jim Carey I was expecting an updated story with some comical twists and some laughs, but there were none.  To be honest, it was boring.  The 3-D was alright, but overall the movie was a big miss.

I'll stick with the Muppet's and Mickey's versions of A Christmas Carol.

I've loved some versions of A Christmas Carol, but for me this one is too loud and in your face for kids under 10 or so.  If you didn't see it in the theater thinking you'd save money and buy it for this holiday season, I have to say I don't recommend it.  If you want a fun family version of this, I recommend going instead with Mickey's Christmas Carol or The Muppet Christmas Carol!

I saw this in the theater with my kids and spent the whole movie helping my son cover his ears in anticipation of the next loud surprise.  When the ghost of Christmas present screams and writhes while he rapidly ages and turns to dust was a low point; it required some convincing that staying for the end would be worth our while.

Just with the shear amount of material they included in this package, the weak sections are buried by getting a great overall product for the money.

I assume one is reading this as a fan of this version so I will skip the content review except to say this is a dark version and there are several scenes that when played in the store scared some of the younger kids. The picture quality is as expected, with flawless details and amazing depth carried throughout. The colors and saturation look exquisite and there are plenty of chances for failure with that floating candle ghost and the amount of dark alleys and rooms. The special features are a serious mixed bag though.

* Making of/Capturing Dickens, 14:39 minutes. Visually narrated by a very irritating actress trying to be funny but she wasn't. Screening it for customers had them asking to fast forward past her to get to the few good points of how they made the film, it is worth skipping this option and watching the next one:
* On set with Sammi, 2 minutes. Short but very informative look into how they did the motion capture effects with her - short but to the point and worthy.
* Deleted scenes, 6 @ 8:39 minutes with quick Zemeckis intro. All are in rough format with the actual actor face(s) placed on the animated characters. Not fun to watch as the format gets distracting. Better at that point to watch the main feature with the PiP.
* 25 Days of Christmas. Cannot stress enough the frustration and unworthiness of this feature. If you do perform this function make sure your player is smoking fast. After it loads up, 25 icons appear on your screen that when selected, a quick or fun little Christmas icon pops up and goes away just as fast, then goes back to menu. It does not let you select ahead so by the time I got to 9 I was fried.
* Blu Ray 3D info with the Lion King critters, 4:13 minutes. A marketing promo for the new format with some stock footage from the films of two of the critters. Skipper.
* Dig Copy promo.
