The Polar Express and Beowulf were fresh and original cinematic milestones.  This was not.  Having watched Alastair Sim, George C. Scott, and Reginald Owen pour their hearts out in earlier versions, they bring an emotional punch that no CGI character can EVER match.  Also with an over-emphasis on action scenes here, it seemed Zemeckis was sacrificing fluidity for the sake of showing what his computers can do.

Apparently, a lot of people like this film.  So, it looks like I'm a lone wolf here.  However, opinions are like noses.  Everybody's got one, usually with a couple of holes in it.  This one's mine.

From an artistic viewpoint, the new Robert Zemeckis film from the man who gave us THE POLAR EXPRESS, is another of his animated features using the motion picture capture technique that allows the actors to play several roles--and the cinematography is exceptionally well done.

JIM CARREY, as miserly Ebenizer Scrooge, looks nothing like his real self. He's a perfect Scrooge, using his voice and mannerisms to great effect, never overplaying the role as you might expect he would.

The visit from three spirits is more frightening than usual, since Zemeckis decided to throw everything he could into startling special effects--sometimes with very gruesome results. The sight of Marley's Ghost with a flapping jaw that has to be realigned by Marley is just one of the "extra" touches. Some of the "spirit" scenes are too intense for small children and more likely to frighten them than anything else.

There are times when the story remains very faithful to the Dickens book, sometimes even word for word. But when Zemeckis decides to show off what the camera can do with flying aerial scenes zooming over Victorian London, it begins to stray a bit. Biggest stray is a chase scene that has a miniature Scrooge going through drain pipes to escape an oncoming coach and horses trying to run him down.

The lovely score by Alan Silvestri blends perfectly with the on screen action and includes a number of traditional Christmas favorites. GARY OLDMAN and COLIN FIRTH do well in key supporting roles but it's really Carey's show all the way. He plays several main characters with great skill.

Not quite as festive as you might expect, it's a darker version of Scrooge, handsomely executed so that many of the scenes look like Victorian illustrations from the novel.

Warning: This is not a child's version of the tale. Parents should be advised that some of the content is too gruesome for young kids. Personally, I enjoyed it and I'm glad I stayed to hear Andreas Boccelli's beautiful voice over the end credits.

I just saw this movie in the theater.  I just loved it.  The animation is so life like.  Now I did see it in 3D which was outstanding and added to the enjoyment of this film.  The story is the original story which I'm sure you've all seen some version of it and it keeps very true to the original.  It was just a feel good movie.  Jim Carrey did a good job as scrooge.  I had tears in my eyes at the end.  I buy about one movie every couple of years and I plan on buying this one so for me that is saying something.

Walt Disney's Buena Vista Productions and Robert Zemekis's adds twists and turns and "magic" to this new depiction of the Charles Dickens classic tale.  Imagine riding one of the dioramas at the theme park and watching Zemekis's perennial Christmas favorite, The Polar Express, one can imagine what to expect from this very imaginative version.

The digital technology and computerized animation spotlight this film.  But in order to experience the special effects, one must absolutely see the IMAX 3-D edition.  The 3-D glasses may be somewhat of an inconvenience, especially for those who wear prescription eyeglasses, but all worth it once viewers see the eye-popping scenes that provide the extravagance, fast-paced, and full-dimensional senses of the entire film, such as the winter snowfall that one can almost imagine touching as well as Ebenezer Scrooge glaring his notorious facial expressions; Jim Carrey does a fine job playing Scrooge as well as the almost unrecognizable Ghost of Christmas Present.  And in addition, there is certainly plenty of fun and frolicking within the film to add the Christmas spirit to one's holiday film viewing, and one scene in particular is where the Ghost of Christmas Past takes Scrooge back to revisit one of the most jubilant periods in his life where jolly old Mr. Fezziwig hosts the Christmas ball filled with music, laughter, and dancing.  And lastly, what would A Christmas Carol be like without the London city streets and their quaint Victorian dcor that adds even more sprinkles of Christmas throughout the film?

Indeed, one can go on and on about the numerous surprises throughout the film and the jaw-dropping scenes.  But after the last credit flickers on the screen, Christmas film aficionados will most likely want to see the film more than once.

You all know the story, so I'll just skip to what's great about this version.  "The Polar Express" has become a Christmas classic to me so I really enjoyed Robert Zemeckis' "Christmas Carol."  To me, it was simply magical.  I've always enjoyed the Victorian London films such as "Gaslight" or "The Picture of Dorian Gray" with the fog, snow, & gaslit streets.  This is really as if you're experiencing the story yourself with Scrooge.  You're transported into the story & to me, that's what makes this film special.  It's the best 3-D movie ever!  This is a must-see in 3-D this holiday season.  Merry Christmas early!  Da' Wolf

I was a little worried at first when I heard Disney was making an animated version of Charles Dicken's classic, but boy was I pleasantly surprised!  I saw Disney's A Christmas Carol in 3D at my local IMAX theatre and was swept away both visually and emotionally by the film.  The animation is wonderful, the cast was wonderful and the music was wonderful... Andrea Bocelli did a song for this movie that was absolutely beautiful.

I've always been partial to the 1930's version of A Christmas Carol but Disney's version is right on par with the earlier one.  The movie kept to it's classic roots and had just enough "Disney Essence" to make it fun and emotionally fulfilling.  Go see this... You won't be disappointed!

I love this story and have taught it in my English classes so I am very familiar with it.  There have been many versions but I have to admit I am a bit picky about the ones I really like.  I will add this to the list of the versions I will watch again and again.

The story stuck very closely to the book, using the same dialogue in most cases.  Nothing is lost in the story.  The characters were designed as they described in the book, which is not often the case.  The details in the homes, offices and in the city were magnificent.  It was almost like getting a history lesson in the bargain.  The movie did not hesitate to include the hunger and starvation that were a part of London in the mid-19th century.  There was a bit of comedy but it is not really a comedic book so it was kept to a minimum.  A few details were added to accommodate the 3-D but they fit in well with the movie.  Nothing vital was taken out and nothing unnecessary was added

The animation was wonderful.  The details were minute, even down the wind-chaffed red cheeks and noses of the Londoners.  At one point I could see the pores on Scrooge's nose.  I saw this movie in 3-D and I highly recommend it.  I see this as the future of movies, the effect was fantastic.  I am not a fan of Jim Carey but he did a good job in this rather than going over the top as he often does.

Highly, highly recommended although parts of the movie might be a little scary for very young children.

This has been one heckofa year for animation films.  I can think of at least 3 movies that should get nominated: Disney's A Christmas Carol, Ponyo and Up.  I have no idea to which film I would give the Oscar because they were all good.  I loved everything about this film--especially the visuals.  (I really felt like I was roaming the streets of old London.)  I loved how they incorporated "Hark The Herald Angels Sing" into the movie.  I loved how faithful the movie was to the Dickens classic.  Arguably the best adaptation of A Christmas Carol.  Go see it.  Highly recommended.

This film is not a mere movie, but an experience.  Everything about A Christmas Carol, the performances, computer imagery, music, interpretation of Dicken's story is astounding.  I have seen and own all the associated films, with the exception of the 1908 version; but Zemckis' film is by far the best, because it remains true to Charles Dicken's original story. Not only is this a true companion to Dicken's story, but it also allows the viewer to see and understand the world in which the author lived and wrote.  It is not just Christmas entertainment, but an experience beyond our own.

I was worried when I learned Jim Carrey would star in Disney's production of "A Christmas Carol". There has never been a more perfect holiday tale and I was concerned about the possibility of an over-the-top Carrey performance. As it turns out, Jim Carrey was wonderful...HOWEVER, since seeing the movie I'm wondering what the developers of the project were thinking? The first fifteen minutes of the film had me believing I was viewing a version  that would join the Alastair Sim and George C. Scott versions in the holiday classics hall-of-fame. However, as the film continued the purity of Dickens' story was compromised with chase scenes and a shrinking Ebenezer Scrooge. Come on!! The screen time could have been better used telling the complete story and developing the other major characters...Bob Cratchit, Tiny Tim, his nephew Fred and Belle. These characters were crucial to Scrooge's reclamation and their importance were, for the most part, trivialized. There were stellar moments...for example, the visitation by Marley's ghost and the scene in the Cratchit home after Tiny Tim's death, but they were too few and far between. Visually the film was absolutely stunning! Some of the "special effects" were wonderful...others just didn't fit the story. The problem with the film, I believe, is that the target audience was not well defined. It appeared at times to target an adult audience and then it would abruptly shift to some rediculous scene clearly intended to satisfy children. If I had wanted to see a children's version I would have rented "Mickey's Christmas Carol" or "A Muppet Christmas Carol". The film is basically true to Dickens' marvelous story but is, at best, a ghostly apparition (pun intended) of the original...it just didn't have enough substance. Entertaining? Yes. Worthwhile seeing? Yes, particularing at an IMAX theater. But if you love Charles Dickens' masterpiece, be prepared to set your expectations a little lower.

Ever since it was first published in 1843, Charles Dickens' tale of miserly Scrooge and his redemption at the hands of various ghosts has long entranced readers with its message of holiday cheer.  It has been adapted numerous times for both stage and screen with a wide variety of distinguished actors such as Alistair Sim and George C. Scott taking on the Scrooge role.  This time, director Robert Zemeckis takes on the familiar story with the help of 3-D motion capture animation and the rubber-limbed talents of Jim Carrey.  What emerges is a flick that, despite its tendency to overuse the 3-D tricks of the trade, is a very faithful adaptation of the Dickens' work in both mood and detail.  In an unusual twist, Carrey not only tackles the role of miserly Scrooge in all his incarnations, but also the roles of all three of the Christmas Spirits who haunt him.  To his credit, Carrey chooses to underplay the miser, making him more believable as a result. He's also very effective in his interpretations of Christmas Past and Yet to Come, with only Christmas Present displaying any hint of his usual penchant to overact.  Carrey is also given solid support by Gary Oldman as Marley's Ghost and Bob Cratchit, Bob Hoskins' Fezziwig and Old Joe, and Robin Wright Penn's Belle and Fan.  Colin Firth provides a nice contrast to Carrey in his role of Fred, Scrooge's nephew.

Zemeckis presents a handsome production that faithfully recreates Victorian London, supported by a wonderful soundtrack by Alan Silvestri.  Zemeckis' screenplay also does justice to the tale by presenting many of the darker themes that tend to get ignored in many other adaptations.  Indeed, it should be noted that some of the images might be considered too strong for very young audiences.  Overall, this film proves to be a delightfully strong entry into the list of worthy CAROL adaptations and definitely worth seeing.

A stooped and crooked curmudgeon walks the streets of Olde London Towne, scaring off beggars, bedraggled but merry carolers, the well-meaning businessmen trying to provide a bit of charity, and in general, anyone who dares to make merry in his presence, including his nephew Fred (voice by Colin Firth).  That old man is Ebenezer Scrooge (Jim Carrey) the sole remaining partner of the countinghouse of Scrooge and Marley. And, it's Christmas Eve, the seventh anniversary of Marley's death.

Having decried his faithful clark, Bob Cratchit (Gary Oldman) for 'robbing him' when he wants the entire day of Christmas off, Scrooge limps his way home to a solitary dinner. Little does he know his former partner, Jacob Marley (voiced by Gary Oldman) is coming in spirit to visit him and offer him one last chance at redemption.  Three ghosts will visit him this Christmas Eve night--if he doesn't accept them, he could end up with a fate as bad as Marley's.

"Christmas Carol" is for the most part faithful to the Dickensian classic.  Robert Zemeckis has, of course, added some heart-breaking and fearsome twists to the three manifestations of Christmasses Past, Present and Future. He's also given Scrooge almost the face I envisioned when I first read the story many years ago.  He's a hawk-nosed, hard eyed, bitter pill of an old man who looks like he's 'stewed in his own bitter pudding' for many years. Carrey's performance is spot-on with just the right hints of humor to keep the film from getting too bleak. London is lovingly rendered in white show and industrial ash, a mix of prosperity and poverty of which Charles Dickens would have recognized and approved as a landscape for his story.  The feel of the place is so real I wanted a bowl of hot soup to warm me after.  The final glory and benediction was Andreas Boccelli singing "God Bless us Everyone."

This film's going to be a classic for years to come. I'm definitely purchasing the Blu Ray as soon as the disk becomes available.  One caution:  though this film is by Disney, it is not for very young children.  Some of the ghostly images scared the younger kids in the audience.

Rebecca Kyle, November 2009

Jim Carrey voices Scrooge in Robert Zemeckis' version of a Christmas Carol. You know the story, he's mean and self-centered and on Christmas eve he's visited by 3 ghosts. But this version is still very worth seeing due to the great animation and the fine work by Jim Carrey.

  I expected Jim Carrey to be extremely annoying voicing Scrooge, as well as playing the 3 spirits. He's pretty restrained though and that's good since he gives his best performances when he's not over-acting. Zemeckis is good at making this kind of movie but he's too good to just make animated movies. I'm hoping that his next is a live action film. I mean, this is the guy that made Back to the Future, Who Framed Roger Rabbit, Romancing the Stone and Forrest Gump. Still, he deserves one of his animated movies to be nominated for best animated film and this one deserves it the most.
GREAT
A classy take on a classic movie
A good rendition of the story. I'm partial to the George C. Scot version but this is a nice change.

There are so many versions of A Christmas Carol, but this newest version has got to be the best of them all. It features Jim Carrey as not a funny character, but rather as Ebeneezer Scrooge, and as the three ghosts of Christmas. This is not a movie for children but rather for fans of the original story, and can get quite scary at times. The music is so good, and it really gets one in the mood for Christmas. Even though this movie is set around Christmas time, you can watch it anytime! Overall, if you love action and suspenseful films, you will love this movie!
